column1:
As a teacher in Oakland in the late 1990s::: Professor Ernest Morrell tried something different to get kids engaged.

He and another teacher introduced elements of pop culture such as rap songs into their classrooms as a way to engage the students with topics that kids know and care about. The goal was to start where they are and connect it to what they needed to learn.

Morrell transitioned from high school teacher to literacy education expert and his research on literacy methods is being used in classrooms in all 50 states: https://go.nd.edu/LiteracyAcrossAmericaWWYFF

FIGHTINGFOR.ND.EDU
Fighting for Literacy Across America

column1:
Congratulations to alumna MacKenzie Isaac! She has been named a 2022 Rhodes Scholar.

As a Rhodes Scholar::: she plans to pursue a Doctor of Philosophy in population health with a longterm goal of working in the area of community health education.

MacKenzie is one of 32 Rhodes Scholars selected from a pool of 826 candidates this year::: and is Notre Dame’s 21st Rhodes Scholar overall and fourth in the past five years.

Read more at https://go.nd.edu/Rhodes2022

column1:
Teaching English at Oakland High in the late 1990s::: Ernest Morrell faced the age-old problem of how to get modern students interested in a canon of long-dead writers and poets. He watched kids muddle through class::: heads down::: interest limited. Then one day::: while teaching Beowulf::: a student’s eyes lit up when he realized the story was similar to a popular rap song. That day::: Professor Morrell saw a spark of joy::: enthusiasm and engagement and wondered how he could give that spark to all his students.

Since then::: Professor Morrell has authored K-5 and 6-12 curricula which are being taught by schools in every state. He’s advocated for teaching that not only improves academic outcomes::: but also personal and social ones. And he’s teaching Notre Dame undergraduates and ACE students to find that spark in their lives and the lives of those around them.

See how he's Fighting for Literacy Across America: https://go.nd.edu/LiteracyAcrossAmericaWWYFF

column1:
Since 2018::: the Notre Dame Linked Experimental Ecosystem Facility #EagleCam at St. Patrick’s County Park in South Bend has allowed viewers to check in on a pair of nesting bald eagles.

They just installed a new full HD camera with better low-light capability and live weather info.

Activity in the nest is expected to increase next month and in the new year as the eagles build up their nest in preparation for laying eggs: https://go.nd.edu/d15520

column1:
Harry Fath and his wife::: Linda::: have committed a $50 million gift::: the largest of its kind in the University’s history::: for use exclusively for undergraduate financial aid.

With their gift::: they will give the University maximum flexibility in how the funds are to be used to help students find a home at Notre Dame. Whether a student is::: for example::: from a low-income background or a middle-class family of five::: the Faths’ gift will enable students of all circumstances to attend and graduate from Notre Dame prepared to make a difference in the world.

https://go.nd.edu/cf621b

NEWS.ND.EDU
Alumnus Harry Fath makes $50 million gift to Notre Dame

column1:
Have you ever wondered the story behind the large crown on display near the elevators on the fifth floor of the Main Building?

The Crown of the Blessed Virgin was originally intended to be placed atop the statue of the Virgin Mary on the Golden Dome::: but University officials made the decision to place it on display in the Basilica of the Sacred Heart when it arrived on campus in 1866 rather than expose it to the elements.

But that's not where the story ends ... Read "The Great Crown Caper" to learn why the crown is now bent and held together precariously with wires and rope: https://go.nd.edu/GreatCrownCaper

column1:
As of 2019::: more than 414:::000 service members and veterans have suffered traumatic brain injuries or TBI.

Graduate student Jayme Hentig is one of them. In 2010::: while on deployment in Afghanistan::: his medical vehicle rolled over during a routine drive. He lost consciousness and woke up in a field hospital with brain and spinal cord injuries.

After a year working with neurosurgeons and neurologists he was told he had exhausted all therapeutic options available. “Then it’s time to create more options:::” Hentig thought.

Now::: Hentig::: a Tillman Scholar::: is working in the lab of David Hyde::: the Kenna Director of the Zebrafish Research Center::: to develop therapies to mitigate the effects of a TBI before it occurs: https://go.nd.edu/MilitaryCommunityFF

column1:
During Jayme Hentig’s career as an Army medic::: he was comfortable caring for others every day. But in 2010::: he went from caregiver to patient after an accident sent his armored vehicle into a rollover. As he grappled with a traumatic brain injury and struggled to regain his cognitive abilities::: doctors eventually told him there were no more therapeutic options. But Jayme was undeterred and decided if there were no existing options::: he would create them.

After earning his undergraduate degree::: Jayme came to Notre Dame to pursue a doctorate in biology. Working with zebrafish::: he was able to better understand how and why brain cells regenerate. After graduation he will continue to study traumatic brain injuries in active-duty service members and veterans as a postdoctoral fellow at the National Institutes of Health.

See how he's fighting for our military community: https://go.nd.edu/MilitaryCommunityFF

Inspired by his dad’s ALS diagnosis::: John Sexton '23 is working to better equip others in powerchairs: https://go.nd.edu/DignityOfIndependenceFF

John is a participant in the Notre Dame Grand Challenges Scholars Program::: which offers admitted students an opportunity to work alongside a faculty mentor and focus on research and solutions for a challenge considered one of the world’s greatest. He also connected with the IDEA Center::: which has helped with the business side of the project from filing patents to navigating FDA regulations to creating an LLC to bring LifeDrive to market.

In the future::: once LifeDrive has buy-in from the ALS community::: John says the next step is to expand to patients with cerebral palsy::: multiple sclerosis::: muscular dystrophy::: stroke or spinal cord injury and anyone else who would benefit from the technology and the hope it provides.

column1:
In 2014::: Shawn Sexton ’88 was diagnosed with bulbar onset sporadic ALS. Realizing he would gradually lose his ability to walk::: communicate and eat::: he and his son::: John::: set out to create opportunities for independence. Together they designed EyeDrive::: an assistive technology that allows Shawn to adjust and drive his wheelchair using eye gaze technology. EyeDrive is one of three current solutions provided by John’s startup::: LifeDrive::: which also provides voice- and caregiver-controlled solutions.

John is now a junior at Notre Dame and a participant in the Grand Challenges Scholars Program::: which::: along with the IDEA Center::: has helped move LifeDrive from an at-home project to an expanded medical device company. John continues to lead its progress to commercialization and distribution::: and he hopes it will soon help other patients like his dad find more independence.

“To try and get this to patients by the time that we graduate is daunting and challenging::: but it pales in comparison to the needs of those patients that we’re trying to serve:::” John says. He explains that getting LifeDrive to patients is so important because not only does it give them technology and independence::: but it gives them hope. That hope::: he says::: can be life-giving.

Learn more: https://go.nd.edu/DignityOfIndependenceFF

Each summer::: Notre Dame’s Center for Civic Innovation (CCI)::: part of the College of Engineering::: operates an internship program in partnership with local governments and organizations.

This year — in a new collaboration with Notre Dame’s Fitzgerald Institute for Real Estate with additional financial support from the Judd A. Leighton Foundation and enFocus — four CCI interns assisted the city of South Bend to develop infill housing in areas where social and economic factors and past public policy have contributed to a lack of safe::: affordable housing options and unfavorable conditions for new investment.

column1:
The EPA plans to unveil new regulations on the PFAS family of chemicals::: know as 'forever chemicals' because they don't break down. They have been linked to thyroid disease::: hypertension::: immunosuppression::: low birthweight and certain cancers:

Physics professor Graham Peaslee studies these chemicals and designed a novel technique to identify their markers in materials. He's found significant levels of PFAS in fast food wrappers::: firefighter turnout gear and::: most recently::: in many cosmetics in the U.S. and Canada.

In 2019::: our "What would you fight for series?" focused on Professor Peaslee's research with firefighter turnout gear. Learn more about his work: https://go.nd.edu/96277a

FIGHTINGFOR.ND.EDU
Fighting to Protect the Brave

Graduate students in the College of Science began working with the St. Joseph County Health Department this summer to monitor public health hazards posed by mosquitoes. As many as 10 species found in Indiana carry diseases such as EEE and West Nile Virus. The students' work is the latest chapter in the University's rich history of vector biology::: the study of how organisms spread infections.

Biological Sciences professor Jason Rohr is working to cut schistosomiasis infections off at the source in Senegal.

His team is using drone and spectral photography to identify and remove vegetation growth that provides a home to the parasite in weedy rivers and lakes in Senegal where people drink::: bathe::: and launder.

Their solution helped solve problems in disease::: energy::: and food scarcity.

Patricia L. Clark::: professor of Chemistry and Biochemistry and associate vice president for research::: has received a Director’s Pioneer Award from the National Institutes of Health. She is the first researcher in Indiana to receive this distinguished award since the program’s inception in 2004.

These awards are given to exceptionally creative scientists advancing high-risk::: high-impact research. Professor Clark will use the award to develop new experimental approaches to measure the sensitivity of proteins to so-called silent changes in the DNA sequence.

Engineering professor Nosang Vincent Myung and his team have developed a prototype of an electronic nose. They used nanoengineered materials to tune its sensitivity and selectivity to mimic the performance and capabilities of a human nose with its approximately 400 scent receptors.

How can an electronic nose be used? It can detect air pollutants or greenhouse gases. It can also uncover drugs and bombs::: sniff out cancer and bacterial infections::: as well as identify natural gas leaks and assess food quality.

column1:
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic over the past year and a half::: many of us have had to make dramatic changes to the way we work::: play::: connect::: and live. But for some::: like Nina Kikel-Coury::: a graduate student with a condition called POTS::: those changes have been especially stringent.

POTS::: postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome::: affects blood flow::: heart rate::: and respiration::: and causes patients to be immunosuppressed. For Nina::: that meant she needed to remain completely isolated during the pandemic and could no longer work alongside others in her research lab. But the team rallied around her.

Her lab mates designated hours when Nina could work alone::: and they continued her experiments when she couldn’t be present. With all this support::: Nina discovered a new cell in the heart—cardiac nexus glia—which may help explain and treat conditions like hers.

Learn more: https://go.nd.edu/ResearchThatMattersWWYFF
column3: Nina is amazing! My young son has POTS and I find her research incredible. Thank you for creating this video to highlight her work pioneering work at the cellular level in POTS research::: thank you for accommodating her challenges so she can make a difference! Stories like Nina’s are so important because they can inspire and inform others with dysautonomia that it is possible to be productive and work and help me part of the solution!

The explosion of wireless applications enabled by advanced radio technologies has placed access to a key natural resource::: the radio frequency spectrum::: at a premium.

The increasing demands of commercial wireless::: especially 5G networks::: as well as the greater needs of scientific::: satellite and defense applications::: among others::: require paradigm shifts in management of the radio spectrum and in coordination of research and development around it.

To address these concerns::: the Notre Dame-led SpectrumX project is bringing together experts from 29 organizations to transform the landscape of spectrum research::: education::: collaboration and management: https://go.nd.edu/3943cf

"We have done a lot::: but it is not enough::: not fast enough. We must act now. This is the Kairos moment."

Earlier this month::: the Vatican and Notre Dame convened the third Vatican Dialogue on Energy Transition. The theme of this year’s discussion was “Just Transition:::” which focuses on the well-being of workers and communities that will bear an undue burden from the transition to a green economy.

Read more about the panel discussions: https://go.nd.edu/VaticanDialogue2021

column7:
Funny that you bring up Kairos…

Many::: many years ago::: I learned about the concept as a high school leader for our annual Flintridge Sacred Heart Kairos Retreat. We reflected upon the need to extend grace during times of crisis::: to embrace opportune moments for connection::: and to recognize critical moments where we are called to action.

Looking at the disconnection and isolation that has shrouded our world during almost two years of pandemic fear::: fighting::: and illness::: I respectfully suggest that the pettiness being shown in University of Notre Dame’s decision to forbid Purdue "All-American" Marching Band/Purdue University/Purdue Football from using the main tunnel for their drum on Saturday is an egregiously tone-deaf message to send the country about how we should be treating each other right now. It certainly doesn’t reflect Christian values.

I did not attend either Notre Dame or Purdue::: but rather spent my years at NU watching both teams trounce us on the football field (until that glorious September day in ‘95… but I digress). I will not be at the game on Saturday.

Some people I care very much about will::: however. James used to play that Big Drum for Purdue back in his day. His father::: Marty O'Hagan::: is a proud Notre Dame alumnus who turned the wall of his dining room into a showcase of his love for his alma mater when he retired and moved here from CA last year. On Saturday morning::: they will head to Indiana with James’s children to watch the teams they both love compete. It was supposed to be the first time the children would see that drum they’ve spent their lives hearing about in person— that it would happen on the pitch their grandfather has loved for most of his lifetime was going to make it all the more special.

But that’s just our story about what the drum means. The stadium will be full of countless others. There will be Purdue fans who have buried someone they loved this year::: fans who are struggling mightily with challenges we will never know::: band members who spent last season unable to play anywhere— Saturday is one of the closest days to normalcy these young people have had in 18 months. The list could go on.

So I ask you::: sincerely::: is the message that Notre Dame wants to send at this particular time of human suffering and exhaustion one of hope::: one of unity::: one of kindness… or do you really want to stand in front of the nation and let such a petty act sabotage your university’s character collateral?

I believe that this is a Kairos moment and that you are called upon to extend grace.

theathletic.com/

no-boom-for-you
-to-purdues-gia
nt-bass-drum/

Everything said in the message above directly contradicts the actions Notre Dame Stadium Notre Dame Football University of Notre Dame is taking against the Purdue Athletics Purdue "All-American" Marching Band on Saturday. How does refusing to allow use of a tunnel by young adults who have spent the better part of a year and a half quarantined— and whose family and friends are paying for seats in your stadium— break down barriers::: recognize the insignificance of divisions::: or show the world that we can be more unified by pulling together?

You’re only being asked to let some musicians share a tunnel for a few hours. To say no to such a simple thing as a Catholic institution modeled after Christ’s teachings is a terrible hypocrisy.
——————————————

Funny that you bring up Kairos…

Many::: many years ago::: I learned about the concept as a high school leader for our annual Flintridge Sacred Heart Kairos Retreat. We reflected upon the need to extend grace during times of crisis::: to embrace opportune moments for connection::: and to recognize critical moments where we are called to action.

Looking at the disconnection and isolation that has shrouded our world during almost two years of pandemic fear::: fighting::: and illness::: I respectfully suggest that the pettiness being shown in University of Notre Dame’s decision to forbid Purdue from using the main tunnel for their drum on Saturday is an egregiously tone-deaf message to send the country about how we should be treating each other right now. It certainly doesn’t reflect Christian values.

I did not attend either Notre Dame or Purdue::: but rather spent my years at NU watching both teams trounce us on the football field (until that glorious September day in ‘95… but I digress). I will not be at the game on Saturday.

Some people I care very much about will::: however. James used to play that Big Drum for Purdue back in his day. His father::: Marty O'Hagan::: is a proud Notre Dame alumnus who turned the wall of his dining room into a showcase of his love for his alma mater when he retired and moved here from CA last year. On Saturday morning::: they will head to Indiana with James’s children to watch the teams they both love compete. It was supposed to be the first time the children would see that drum they’ve spent their lives hearing about in person— that it would happen on the pitch their grandfather has loved for most of his lifetime was going to make it all the more special.

But that’s just our story about what the drum means. The stadium will be full of countless others. There will be Purdue fans who have buried someone they loved this year::: fans who are struggling mightily with challenges we will never know::: band members who spent last season unable to play anywhere— Saturday is one of the closest days to normalcy these young people have had in 18 months. The list could go on.

So I ask you::: sincerely::: is the message that Notre Dame wants to send at this particular time of human suffering and exhaustion one of hope::: one of unity::: one of kindness… or do you really want to stand in front of the nation and let such a petty act sabotage your university’s character collateral?

I believe that this is a Kairos moment and that you are called upon to extend grace.

https://
theathletic.com/
news/
notre-dame-says-
no-boom-for-you
-to-purdues-gia
nt-bass-drum/
QWZIrGanxnI3

The University of Notre Dame will mark the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11::: 2001::: terrorist attacks on the United States in several ways Saturday:

Rev. Edward "Monk" Malloy::: C.S.C.::: will preside over a 30-minute prayer service on South Quad beginning at 8:46 a.m.::: the time the first plane was flown into 1 World Trade Center in lower Manhattan.

The anniversary will also be commemorated immediately prior to the Notre Dame-Toledo football game with a reflection from Fr. Malloy and prayer led by Rev. John I. Jenkins::: C.S.C.::: at approximately 2:20 p.m.

At halftime::: the Notre Dame and University of Toledo marching bands will combine to play “Amazing Grace:::” a performance similar to that of the Notre Dame and Michigan State University bands in the first football game following the terrorist attacks.

column1:
We're kicking off our 15th season of "Would you Fight For" with Fighting to Control Diabetes: https://go.nd.edu/DiabetesWWYFF

For parents of a child with #Type1Diabetes::: stress is relentless. There’s a constant need to monitor blood sugar levels::: and that need doesn’t stop once the child goes to sleep.

Professor Matt Webber ’06 was inspired when a colleague mentioned she and her husband slept in shifts while the other monitored their diabetic child through the night. Since then::: he has been devising material technologies that could be easily applied on or beneath the skin before bedtime. If blood sugar drops::: the material automatically releases medication to stabilize levels.

While distribution is still years away::: Professor Webber hopes that in the future::: his work will help take some of the burden off worried parents and serve as an extra measure of safety for millions with Type 1 #diabetes worldwide.

column1:
On September 11::: 2001::: President Emeritus Rev. Edward A. “Monk” Malloy::: C.S.C.::: was preparing for meetings when his assistant came to tell him that he needed to turn on the television. Like much of the world he stood transfixed at the events as they unfolded and later that day he presided over a Mass of remembrance on South Quad.

He reflects on the events of 9/11 and what followed for the campus community and himself on the latest Notre Dame Stories podcast. Listen: https://go.nd.edu/NDStoriesInStudio
column3: I’ll never forget that day during my senior year on campus. After watching the events unfold on TV that morning::: my girlfriend (now wife of 16 years) and I decided to go for a walk around the lakes to collect our thoughts before attending the campus-wide mass. While walking on a lonely stone path at the farthest point from the center of campus::: we happened to pass by Fr. Malloy who was walking the opposite direction by himself. I’m sure he was trying to collect his thoughts as well. We gave each other a brief glance and quick hello::: but I’ll never forget the solemness and concern that was on his face. I’m assuming he saw the same look on ours as well. That is one of my more vivid memories of that unforgettable day.

column1:
As the #Tokyo2020 Paralympic Games open::: meet world champion and Notre Dame Cross Country/Track & Field star Sam Grewe::: who is going for gold both on the field and in the field of medicine.

We're cheering for both Sam and Notre Dame Swimming/Diving's Ilija Tadic as they compete at the Paralympics!

#ParalympiansMadeHere

Sam Grewe '21 lost his leg to osteosarcoma when he was 13 years old and spent two years undergoing chemotheraphy and treatments in hospitals. He saw first-hand the benefit physicians with a compassionate mindset have on patients::: a practice Dominic Vachon::: Director of the Hillebrand Center for Compassionate Care in Medicine at Notre Dame::: is studying as well.

Since 2011::: nearly 1:::000 students including Sam::: who is training for the Paralympic Tokyo Games and hopes to attend medical school::: have taken the Center's courses designed to teach skills such as personalism::: medical counseling and clinical ethics — the only undergraduates in the country receiving this kind of preparation.

More: https://go.nd.edu/CompassionInMedicine

Lithium-ion batteries have been the top choice for rechargeable batteries for more than a decade::: but they have drawbacks. They are easy to overcharge::: which results in overheating and can cause fires::: and have a limited lifespan.

‘Service with a smile’ plus tipping leads to sexual harassment for majority of service employees::: study shows
column3: wow::: being service oriented::: I always gave the customer what they expected ::: a correct order::: delivered hot::: placed in front of the correct person::: dishes taken away properly::: a bill totaled correctly::: but most of all:::::: to make the customer feel comfortable enough to return. Inappropriate behavior was not allowed from customers... the boss got involved and threw these people out... Why is it that these behaviors still exist... Do we not teach our children that unwanted advances is wrong... I was raised in a Irish Catholic family. My parents went to catholic schools::: as I. My father went to Regis HS in Manhattan and Manhattan College in the Bronx .both on scholorships.. He was admitted to Notre Dame for graduate studies::: his master. my mother got sick with cancer.. He didn't go through with it... We were raised to respect people.. threat thy neighbor as you would treat yourself... I would be more willing to blame the lack of respect these days..

Have you ever logged into your patient health portal and been confused by something you saw in the clinician notes::: test results::: progress documentation and other records uploaded there?

A Notre Dame professor is part of a team working on a web-based natural language processing system that could increase the health literacy of patients who access their records through patient portals.

In other words::: he is helping patients translate their medical records into easy-to-understand terms: https://go.nd.edu/841413

NEWS.ND.EDU
Artificial intelligence tool could increase patient health literacy::: study shows
column3: Portals also distance doctors from patients. A question is sent. A nurse reads it::: speaks to doctor::: writes a response and sends it. A follow-up question requires the same process. If you indicate concern or alarm::: your thoughts are disregarded in the shortest most sterile response. Or you will be asked if you would like an appointment. As a disabled person::: who requires major assistance to get to an appointment::: this is hardly an improvement.

Researchers develop novel method for glucagon delivery

column1:
The Notre Dame Law School's Exoneration Justice Clinic celebrated its first exoneration this week when prosecutors dismissed a murder charge against Andy Royer::: who spent 16 years in prison despite being innocent.

Wrongful convictions are a serious problem nationwide with nearly 2:::700 exonerations granted since 1989. That’s one about every four days.

The Clinic is working on cases in Indiana that the instructors and students believe deserve to be overturned. The clinic also tries to identify the real perpetrator as a means to free its clients::: but also because the victim of the initial crime deserves justice.

Learn more: https://go.nd.edu/WrongfulConvictions

column1:
Our gut microbiome — the ever-changing “rainforest” of bacteria living in our intestines — is primarily affected by our lifestyle::: including what we eat or the medications we take::: most studies show.

But a Notre Dame study has found a much greater genetic component at play than was once known. Knowing that genes in the gut microbiome are heritable opens the door to identifying microbes in the future that are shaped by genetics. In the future::: therapies could be tailored for people based on the genetic makeup of their gut microbiome.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Our genes shape our gut bacteria::: new research shows

The University of Notre Dame Mendoza College of Business has launched its first doctoral programs – the Doctor of Philosophy in Management and the Doctor of Philosophy in Analytics.

The core mission of the programs is to prepare doctoral students for careers in academia at leading business schools where publishing research in top academic journals is prioritized. The programs will also prepare students to work in government or industry::: and will prioritize developing faculty whose academic research aligns with the College’s imperative to “Grow the Good in Business” by contributing to human flourishing with solidarity for all stakeholders::: especially the most vulnerable.

Both programs are accepting applications now::: for a Fall 2022 matriculation.

MENDOZA.ND.EDU

Always bow-tied and bespectacled::: Smith designed dozens of ecclesiastical::: public and residential projects across the country. Fog is one of the most unpredictable and most disruptive aspects of meteorology.

A new five-year study by Engineering professor Harindra Joseph Fernando will improve the fundamental understanding::: detection and predictability of marine sea fog: https://go.nd.edu/34cf49

New research shows that many cosmetics sold in the United States and Canada likely contain high levels of PFAS::: a potentially toxic class of chemicals linked to a number of serious health conditions: https://go.nd.edu/PFASinCosmetics

According to the study::: 56 percent of foundations and eye products::: 48 percent of lip products and 47 percent of mascaras tested were found to contain high levels of fluorine::: which is an indicator of PFAS use in the product.

Studies have linked certain PFAS to kidney cancer::: testicular cancer::: hypertension::: thyroid disease::: low birth weight and immunotoxicity in children.
column3: This is somewhat misleading. PFAS presence is and has been ubiquitous in nonstick cookware and several other avenues of exposure. Absolutely reduce where you can but without context of duration and relative amounts of exposure::: this potential danger is hard to assess.

column1:
In an effort to keep more entrepreneurs in the South Bend-Elkhart region::: the Judd Leighton Foundation is making a pool of $125:::000 available for Notre Dame student entrepreneurs who choose to stay in the South Bend area.

For every dollar The IDEA Center at the University of Notre Dame either invests in or gives to a South Bend-Elkhart-based student venture::: the Foundation will match it until its $125:::000 is depleted. Additionally::: the Judd Leighton Foundation’s donation is meant to keep more student entrepreneurs as entrepreneurs by increasing the amount of money their companies receive as part of their first round of funding::: which is traditionally the most difficult to raise and often the smallest.

IDEACENTER.ND.EDU
Judd Leighton Foundation to Provide up to $125:::000 in Matching Funds for Notre Dame Student Entrepreneurs Who Headquarter in South Bend // IDEA Center // University of Notre Dame

Later this month::: Notre Dame Law School's Religious Liberty Initiative will bring together some of the world's foremost thought leaders on religious freedom for the inaugural Notre Dame Religious Liberty Summit.

The Religious Liberty Initiative is focused on creating and promoting religious liberty scholarship::: and then leveraging those ideas to protect real people of all faiths. The summit will stimulate conversations between scholars::: advocates::: and religious leaders about the future of religious liberty in the United States and around the world.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Law School to host inaugural Notre Dame Religious Liberty Summit on June 28-29

Can four-legged robots be designed to enable them to walk alongside astronauts on other planets?

That's the question John Nganga::: a Ph.D. student in aerospace and mechanical engineering::: will try to answer with a 3-year NASA Space Technology Graduate Research Opportunity award.

The award supports graduate students “who show significant potential to contribute to NASA’s goal of creating innovative new space technologies.” John will conduct his research at Notre Dame during the academic year and will spend summers at a NASA facility collaborating with leading space engineers and scientists.

ENGINEERING.ND.EDU
Ph.D. student receives NASA research award to design strategies to enable four-legged robots to walk alongside astronauts on other planets - College of Engineering

column1:
Many Americans have never heard of the Tulsa Race Massacre of 1921::: but for James O. Goodwin ’61::: the events that took place in his hometown nearly 20 years before he was born shaped his life.

Goodwin is a lifelong Tulsa resident::: practicing attorney and longtime publisher of The Oklahoma Eagle::: the city’s Black newspaper that speaks of those whose stories have long gone untold: https://go.nd.edu/779562

This statue of Rev. William Corby::: C.S.C.::: two-term president of Notre Dame and chaplain of the Civil War's 88th New York Regiment::: was unveiled on campus on Memorial Day 1911. It shows Fr. Corby as he gave absolution to soldiers at the Battle of Gettysburg and is a replica of the statue at Gettysburg National Military Park.

Working in partnership with Notre Dame Admissions and the Notre Dame Alumni Association::: the University of Notre Dame - Office of Military and Veterans Affairs recently launched Route ND::: a recruitment program aimed at encouraging qualified service members to apply to Notre Dame.

Through this program::: alumni members appointed as RouteND ambassadors help their alma mater identify and mentor outstanding enlisted service members with whom they serve::: offer them advice as they navigate the admissions process and::: most importantly::: impart the spirit of Notre Dame that unites everyone as alumni::: family and friends.

Read more: https://go.nd.edu/525eee

On Sunday::: Carla Harris received the 2021 Laetare Medal and sang 'Amazing Grace' to close our Commencement Ceremony.

She left graduates with three of "Carla's Pearls" of wisdom:

1. It is what you do for others that counts.
2. Fear has no place in your success equation. Failure always brings you a gift: experience.
3. There is only one you::: your authenticity is your distinct competitive advantage.

Congratulations to Madeline Owen and Alexis Waldschmidt::: our 2021 valedictorian and salutatorian!

Madeline is a neuroscience/pre-med major in the College of Science::: minored in poverty studies and was a Glynn Family Honors scholar. She was an early inductee into Phi Beta Kappa honor society and has been a member of the University’s Dean’s List since fall 2017. After graduation::: she will attend Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine.

Alexis::: a biological sciences and Chinese double major::: is a member of the University’s Phi Beta Kappa honor society and Dean’s List. Her plans include continuing to work with the O’Tousa Lab as a full-time laboratory technician and continuing her studies in biology::: with the goal of becoming a professor of biological sciences.

Read more about them: https://go.nd.edu/2021ValedictorianSalutatorian

column1:
Jimmy Dunne will deliver the commencement address to Notre Dame’s Class of 2021 and receive an honorary doctor of laws degree at the 176th University Commencement Ceremony on May 23.

Dunne is a Notre Dame Trustee and alumnus who in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11::: 2001::: led the recovery of his company while also providing compassionate and meaningful care to the families of the firm’s employees who lost their lives.

“At a time when our graduates have had to show remarkable resilience in the face of the adversity of the COVID-19 pandemic::: Jimmy is someone who personified resilience in the aftermath of the tragic events 20 years ago:::” Notre Dame President Fr. John Jenkins said. “Through his example::: as well as his words::: he will send off our graduates with a powerful message about commitment::: honor::: integrity and perseverance.”

NEWS.ND.EDU
Jimmy Dunne to deliver commencement address to Notre Dame’s Class of 2021

Last week::: Indiana Michigan Power and Notre Dame flipped the switch on St. Joseph Solar Farm::: a new 210-acre solar facility adjacent to the Indiana Toll Road in Granger::: about seven miles east of Notre Dame.

As a partner in the project::: Notre Dame has agreed to purchase 40 percent of that energy — equal to about 10 percent of the University’s annual need for electricity — in the form of clean energy credits::: which it will use to offset carbon emissions and improve air quality in South Bend and the surrounding community.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Notre Dame::: Indiana Michigan Power 'flip the switch' on new solar facility

column1:
For 125 years::: the Holy Cross brothers — and until 1936 some hardy religious sisters — worked on St. Joseph’s Farm to feed the students::: faculty and administration of Notre Dame. They finally stopped working the farm themselves in 1995 because there weren’t enough of them left who wanted to farm.

Today::: ribbons were cut on a new partnership that carries on the tradition of the farm fueling campus::: with a modern twist. Indiana Michigan Power officially opened a $37 million solar project there that will provide clean energy credits equal to 10 percent of the University’s total demand for electricity::: helping Notre Dame meet its goals around clean::: renewable energy.

Read the history of St. Joseph's Farm: https://go.nd.edu/BeforeTheSunrise

Better World Books::: an online bookseller that donates books and a share of its profits to literacy programs around the globe::: originated as a campus book drive in 2002.

The company recently sold its 100 millionth book and — to mark the occasion — awarded $10:::000 to the Notre Dame Robinson Community Learning Center for the purchase of new and used books. It also plans to bring its bookmobile to the RCLC once coronavirus restrictions are lifted.

“We at Notre Dame must never tire of striving to deepen our appreciation of peoples of every race and ethnic heritage::: celebrating their gifts and discovering the deeper humanity that binds us. We must fight against every form of bigotry and exclusion::: for it is only by doing so that we can be the community and institution we aspire to be.

We are called to fulfill the promise of this commitment every month and::: indeed::: every day at Notre Dame. Let us::: though::: make this month of May::: Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage month::: a time to ensure members of these communities are fully included in the Notre Dame community. We will all be richer for it.”

Read Fr. Jenkins' full statement on Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month: https://go.nd.edu/41dda1

NEWS.ND.EDU
Statement: Father Jenkins on Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month

Looking for something to do this weekend? Grab your popcorn and tune into the 32nd Annual Notre Dame Student Film Festival: Quarantined!

The festival will be streamed on FTT’s YouTube channel at 7 p.m. Sunday::: May 2 and will screen films that were made by undergraduate students during the past year as class projects in the Department of Film::: Television and Theatre.

In years past::: the festival has featured the first films of future award-winning filmmakers. It has served as the springboard for successful careers in every aspect of the industry::: where ND Student Film Festival alumni have worked on everything from “Saturday Night Live” to “La La Land.”

Stream: https://go.nd.edu/2021NDStudentFilmFestival

“I am often asked how Dante is relevant for today. The answer is very simple: Dante confronted a world that was culturally::: politically and spiritually in profound crisis.”

Political Science professor Daniel Philpott has received the 2021 Distinguished Scholar Award from the International Studies Association’s Religion and International Relations Section.

Philpott::: the section’s awards committee noted::: is a key figure in the first generation of scholars to incorporate religion into the study of international relations. His research focuses on the relationship between religion and democracy::: ethics::: peace-building::: reconciliation and religious freedom.

As Pope Francis wrote in his 2015 encyclical::: Laudato Si’::: “We are faced not with two separate crises::: one environmental and the other social::: but rather with one complex crisis which is both social and environmental.”

Inspired by Laudato Si’ and the Holy Father’s continued emphasis on these issues::: the 2021 Notre Dame Forum will engage in a series of conversations devoted to the theme “Care for Our Common Home: Just Transition to a Sustainable Future.”

Notre Dame Forum 2021 will explore ‘Care for Our Common Home: Just Transition to a Sustainable Future’

column1:
About every 25 years since 1966::: botanists have completed campus surveys to record the variety and location of all trees::: vines and shrubs on campus.

That 1966 survey lists 482 woody plants while the most recent yielded more than 10:::000 plantings. The latest survey also includes information on the condition of each planting::: as well as the location of donor memorial tree plaques.

“This is one of the most comprehensive surveys of trees and plants on any campus:::” said Ronald Hellenthal::: director of the Museum of Biodiversity and biological sciences professor emeritus. “Notre Dame is certainly one of the first universities to develop a project of this magnitude.”

ND.EDU
Growing Beauty

column1:
“We welcome the verdict in the trial of Derek Chauvin for the death of George Floyd. The appalling cruelty depicted in the video of Mr. Floyd’s death along with the terrible legacy of the treatment of Black men and women in police custody led many to hope for a reckoning in this case::: and we believe justice was done. May this verdict be a first step on a road to police reform and a renewed battle against racism and bigotry anywhere and in any form.

“We pray for the eternal rest of George Floyd::: and for his family and loved ones. We pray too for all police officers::: the vast majority of whom serve the public professionally and compassionately.”

- Rev. John I. Jenkins::: C.S.C.
column3: You shame your instruction! Colleges like yours no longer provide true education::: they only provide a paper at the end indicating that a person has passed through your portals. No real learning going on! Shame on you!
column4: Why do you feel the need to get involved with politics...
column5: Justice that happens everyday in our world class legal system. Bless the men and women in blue who protect us and enforce our laws.
column6:
“Do the people who are always demanding that there be more “training” for police ever say that the hoodlums that the police have to deal with should have had more training by their parents instead of having grown wild::: like weeds”...words spoken by a black educator...Thom
as Sowell.
Be careful what you ask for::: because once the people who bleed blue stop caring::: the darkness of the world will have no keepers.
column7: Thank you Father Jenkins for your support of Social Justice which is at the foundation of many of the teaching of the Catholic faith. As an alumni of the Notre Dame Saint Mary's Community your work for Social Justice and willingness to take a STAND is appreciated.
column8: Fr Jenkins - as president of the University of Notre Dame it would serve the alumni::: the students::: the subway alumni and contributors to the exceptional large endowment to keep your political opinions to yourself and allow us the freedom to make our own decisions. Blessings
column9: We don’t need “police reform”. We need police officers who adhere to the strict training protocols of every police department in the US. We have more than enough laws to handle this which can readily be seen from the prosecution of Mr. Chauvin. We don’t need to overturn the policing of America because of an outlier like Chauvin. Instead::: we need to prosecute wrongdoing police officers and teach our children to comply with lawful orders of police officers and take their grievances in court. Teach our children to take ownership of their own actions. The “appalling cruelty” as reference by Fr. Jenkins is not indicative of the majority of police officers and instead is indicative of a very small minority of police officers. What hubris that Fr. Jenkins can opine that “we believe justice was done”! Who is he speaking for? All of the Notre Dame community? May George Floyd Rest In Peace and may eternal rest grant unto him. Kevin G. Mescall::: Esq. ND Class of ‘79.
column10:
This was accountability:::
justice hasn’t happened yet because the system allowed for this to happen in the first place. More work needs to be done.

My prayer is that our country will come together. I hope Christians will set the example and lead the way. Jesus told His disciples::: “This is My commandment::: that you love one another as I have loved you" (John 15:12). George Floyd’s life mattered—every life matters to God."

Kathleen W. Andrews::: a Trustee emerita of the University of Notre Dame and the first woman to serve as a Fellow of the University::: died Friday. She was 84.

“As a Fellow::: Trustee::: advisory council member::: benefactor::: counselor and friend::: Kathy served Notre Dame in these and many other capacities for more than four decades. Her wise and compassionate presence will be deeply missed by all of us who knew and loved her.

“Our condolences go out to the Andrews family and Kathy’s many friends. We mourn her passing::: pray for the repose of her soul and celebrate her inspiring life.”

Congratulations to juniors Tarik Brown and Gregory Miller! They have been named 2021 Truman Scholars::: becoming the University’s 10th and 11th Truman Scholars since 2010.

Tarik is a computer science major and Hesburgh Program in Public Service minor with interests in technical education for students from low-income backgrounds and in bias and inequity in law enforcement::: the criminal justice system and education.

Greg is an economics and applied and computational mathematics and statistics double major and a Hesburgh Program in Public Service and constitutional studies double minor with an interest in housing rights for low-income tenants.

Learn more about them: https://go.nd.edu/1aff16

column1:
With the support of Fr. Ted Hesburgh::: the Black Alumni of Notre Dame (BA of ND) was founded in May 1987::: during the first Black Alumni Reunion::: with the mission to enhance the presence and experiences of African Americans across the Notre Dame family.

Soon thereafter::: the BA of ND established the Frazier Thompson Scholarship::: a financial aid fund named in honor of the University’s first Black graduate.

Now::: the Frazier Thompson Scholarship has been broadened to provide grants in seven categories to undergraduate::: graduate and professional students who have helped achieve the fund’s primary goal of enhancing the experience of Black students.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Black Alumni of Notre Dame expands scope of Frazier Thompson Scholarship

column1:
Unable to participate in traditional job shadowing due to the coronavirus pandemic::: three friends on the leadership board for the Notre Dame Preprofessional Society created their own opportunity.

They designed a class where Notre Dame alumni physicians shared their experiences with the next generation of allied health workers — almost like a virtual “job shadowing” experience accompanied by upper-level biological and medical physics readings.

Thirty-nine students took "Biomedical Case Studies in Medicine:::" the one-credit course they created::: during the Winter Session.

ND.EDU
Out of the “Shadow”

column1:
70% of students have been or plan to be vaccinated.

If we can reach 90% by April 15::: we hope to relax some of our health protocols including allowing inter-hall visits in common lounges::: eliminating the mask requirement outdoors on campus for gatherings of 25 or less::: and restoring some outdoor recreational opportunities::: such as basketball and volleyball.

Help us get there:

- Upload your vaccination information to the UHS patient portal if you received a dose off campus. Use the document upload feature and choose "Immunizations" as the document type.

- Schedule an appointment using the link in the email from noreply@coronavirus.in.gov with subject line “You are eligible for the COVID-19 vaccine at your campus location."

column8: Can Father Jenkins see the future? How dare he announce that this vaccine is “completely safe.” Scientists aren’t even for sure how long this vaccine will be effective. It’s possible it would be needed every six months. They aren’t even sure! We aren’t just talking about a one-and-done vaccine::: this could mean potentially continually injecting the students over and over again. Can he guarantee these students aren’t going to have any fertility problems in the years to come because of this intrusive mandate? That they won’t end up having an organ issue or heart palpitations? There’s too much of the unknown here to force this upon your entire student body. As I’ve said before::: WHY is it ONLY a student decree? This is their home right now. Anyone invading their space should have to go through the same "protections for the community" if they are so forced: Professors::: clergy::: staff::: guests of mass or weddings or sporting events::: visitors to campus::: otherwise this virus can be passed on and on. Come on. It’s absolutely terrible to see so many suggesting these students just “go somewhere else” if they don’t like it. It’s not that easy. For one::: many schools are already finished with their admissions process for the upcoming fall. For another::: those who rely on student financial aid know that their best packages come as an incoming freshman who commits for 4 years. Switching schools now is devastating especially for those with limited financial resources. How villainous to leave these kids without a choice on a vaccine with such limited scope. And after they are already committed and engaged at their school::: that’s just wrong. And how dare Notre Dame decide this is a student ONLY intimidation? If it’s so darned wonderful and important for the community::: then the entire ND community::: or anyone coming onto that campus should be subject to the same senseless regulation. They won’t be::: because it’s exploratory::: and they know it. My heart goes out to the students in this predicament as well as their families. I suggest having a lawyer look into the plausibility of creating this experimental student ONLY regulation after their scholars are already enrolled and committed.

column125:
A few thoughts for those claiming that the FDA hasn't approved the vaccine::: as if to say that the FDA thinks it's a large mystery and just doesn't know what to make of the vaccines.

I got the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine and beforehand had looked into it in some depth. The testing::: as described::: seemed clinically robust-\-\randomi
zed double blind placebo-control
led trials with a total of over 50:::000 participants. According to Pfizer's press release at the conclusion of the Phase 3 trial:::

"The only Grade 3 (severe) solicited adverse events greater than or equal to 2% in frequency after the first or second dose was fatigue at 3.8% and headache at 2.0% following dose 2. Consistent with earlier shared results::: older adults tended to report fewer and milder solicited adverse events following vaccination."

And here's what the FDA says at their website ("Learn More About COVID-19 Vaccines"):

"How safe are the COVID-19 vaccines?

"The FDA evaluated data from clinical studies that included tens of thousands of people. The data from these studies clearly show that the known and potential benefits of the FDA-authorized COVID-19 vaccines greatly outweigh the known and potential risks.

"Millions of doses of FDA-authorized COVID-19 vaccines have been given to people all around the country. Serious adverse events following vaccination are very rare. No serious::: life-threatenin
g allergic reactions occurred in clinical study participants::: however::: after getting a COVID-19 vaccine in their community::: a few people had anaphylaxis (a severe::: life-threatenin
g allergic reaction that happens within seconds or minutes of exposure to an allergen). Because of this remote chance of severe allergic reaction::: health care providers may ask you to stay at the place where you received a vaccine for monitoring for 15 to 30 minutes.

"To date the FDA and other government agencies have not identified any new safety signals that raise questions about the risks and benefits of COVID-19 vaccines. A safety signal is information from one or more sources::: such as federal surveillance programs::: that suggests an adverse event may potentially be related to a vaccine or medicine and that further evaluation through additional studies or close monitoring may be needed."

It's true that we are only into the early period of vaccination for COVID-19::: but according to the CDC about 56 million Americans have been fully vaccinated so far. If there were widespread dire consequences I believe we'd have been hearing about them. Perhaps there are some as yet unknown long-term nefarious effects; but there is no evidence for that proposition-\-\it
's simply conjecture.

In late July 2019::: the morning light shone through the windows of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre and bounced off the hundreds of lamps and chandeliers::: brass statues and icons::: and coated the shrine at the spot of the crucifixion in a glowing white brilliance. A small group of Notre Dame students visiting took in the sight and then traversed down a flight of steps and across the main hall to the shrine of Jesus’ tomb.

Read how this holy site took on new significance for these students experiencing Notre Dame's presence in Jerusalem: https://go.nd.edu/LivingStones

I would never have gotten that had we not been there and witnessed it. Love you!

Civil and Environmental Engineering and Earth Sciences Professor Clive Neal is searching for natural resources in lunar rock with samples collected from the Moon during an Apollo mission in 1972.

He hopes findings will make a continual presence on the Moon economical and power humans further into space.

ND.EDU
The Fan of the Moon
column3: Do we assume that this research into the possibility of finding natural resources on the Moon is backed by some large corporation on Earth? Given current health and safety guidelines regarding the coronavirus pandemic::: the Basilica of the Sacred Heart will offer an adjusted schedule for Holy Week and implement a reservation request system for Easter Sunday Masses.

Triduum services::: which include the Mass of the Lord’s Supper::: Celebration of the Lord’s Passion and the Easter Vigil::: will be open to students::: faculty and staff and held in the Purcell Pavilion at the Joyce Center.

Easter Sunday Masses will be offered at the Basilica of the Sacred Heart and open to the campus community and visitors. Reservations are required for all Masses. A reservation request form::: available at CampusMinistry.nd.edu/HolyWeek-Easter::: will close at noon EDT on March 24.

column1:
Janice Poorman::: director of formation and field education and professor of the practice in the Department of Theology at the University of Notre Dame::: died Wednesday (March 10) after a courageous battle with breast cancer. She was 68.

Poorman served for 28 years in numerous positions at Notre Dame::: including associate dean of the Graduate School and director of formation and field education in the master of divinity program. She was among the designers of two of the University’s most innovative initiatives in support of the Catholic Church — the Echo Faith Formation Leadership Program::: where she continued as a senior formation advisor::: and Notre Dame Vision::: in which she taught the undergraduate “Mentors in Faith” course. She also regularly presented at retreats and formation workshops and as a facilitator of the art of theological reflection.

NEWS.ND.EDU
In memoriam: Theologian Jan Poorman

Did you know the Monday after Daylight Savings Time begins in the U.S. is known as #NationalNappingDay?

Psychology Professor Jessica Payne's research indicates all of us could benefit if we took a nap each day. The trick is keeping your naps brief enough::: or long enough::: so that you don’t wake up in the middle of a sleep cycle and feel groggy or fatigued after.

ND.EDU
Your Brain on Sleep

In this episode of One Big Question::: Director of Campus Ministry Fr. Pete McCormick and Lynnette Wukie '21 discuss supplemental testing with Vice President for Campus Safety and University Operations Mike Seamon.

“There is no such thing as a safe level of lead::: and our goal with these screening kits is to help people identify their home’s lead ‘hot spots.’"

The Notre Dame Lead Innovation Team’s pilot lead screening program is expanding to Marion and Vigo counties. The program will now provide free lead screening kits at the request of residents living in St. Joseph::: Marion and Vigo counties::: which are then analyzed on campus by researchers who share the results with residents.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Notre Dame::: IUPUI to provide free home lead screening kits to Marion and Vigo counties

A mass inoculation clinic at the Compton Family Ice Arena will operate from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. March 26 and 27 and will be available to Indiana residents throughout the region who meet the state’s age and other eligibility guidelines at the time.

The initiative::: announced today by the state health department::: is part of a statewide effort to quickly administer vaccinations to as many Hoosiers as possible. All clinics will require advance registration.

The mass inoculation clinic is apart from a previously announced administration site for the Notre Dame community that the University is pursuing separately with the state health department.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Notre Dame to operate mass vaccination clinic for northern Indiana residents March 26 and 27

A face comes into focus on the Zoom call. The doctor takes a deep breath::: ready to deliver a difficult diagnosis. But the patient is not a real patient - at least not now::: and the “doctor” is not a doctor - at least not yet.

Each week::: actors on Zoom are helping preprofessional students learn essential communication strategies in a Hillebrand Center for Compassionate Care in Medicine at Notre Dame course.

The class fosters empathy and interpersonal skills::: fulfilling the Hillebrand Center’s mission to “restore the spirit of compassion in healthcare by advancing the application of the science of compassion at every level of medical training and practice to transform clinician well-being and patient care.”

(Photo taken in Fall 2019)

SCIENCE.ND.EDU
Actors make medical counseling skills course come to life // News // College of Science // University of Notre Dame

Electrical Engineering Assistant Professor Thomas O’Sullivan and his team are developing a powerful::: pocket-sized optical imager that may once have seemed like the stuff of science fiction.

It could help a doctor scan for the earliest signs of disease during an office visit. The device::: he explains::: could also be used to monitor progression and treatment — from breast cancer to brain function to personal health — with more exacting precision.

NEWS.ND.EDU
A powerful::: pocket-sized optical imager::: no longer science fiction

column1:
Notre Dame’s Wilson Sheehan Lab for Economic Opportunities partnered with Catholic Charities Fort Worth to evaluate its Padua pilot - a new approach to social work aiming to disrupt poverty for good.

After 24 months::: their findings revealed real improvements in self-sufficiency & labor market outcomes for participants.

“Our study indicates that Padua offers a promising path out of poverty for individuals and families struggling to make ends meet:::” said Jim Sullivan::: Professor of Economics and LEO co-founder. “And the urgency to help those in need has been heightened by the economic impact of the pandemic::: which has pushed nearly 8 million more people into poverty in just the past six months.”

ND.EDU
A Clearer Path Out of Poverty

column1:
Sophie White::: a professor in the Department of American Studies::: has won the prestigious 2020 Frederick Douglass Book Prize for her work “Voices of the Enslaved: Love::: Labor::: and Longing in French Louisiana.”

The prize::: sponsored by Yale University’s Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery::: Resistance and Abolition and the Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History::: recognizes the best book published in English on slavery::: resistance or abolition. It is considered one of the most distinguished awards for the study of global slavery. Professor White will receive the award in an online celebration tomorrow::: February 23.

NEWS.ND.EDU
American studies professor wins Frederick Douglass Book Prize

column1:
As those of you who have been part of this event in years past know::: we begin Walk the Walk Week each year on the eve of Martin Luther King Jr. Day with a candlelight prayer service in the Rotunda of the Main Building. We gather there to reflect on what we have done and what more we might do to become the community we seek to be.

This year::: since we are not able to gather in person::: we encourage you to take a few moments with us to join us in prayer and reflection as Walk the Walk Week begins and we mark the first Sunday of Lent.

While the global pandemic prevents us from gathering in our customary ways::: it need not prevent us from thinking deeply about the issues of equity and justice facing our nation and our communities::: or from committing ourselves to our next steps as we seek to contribute to::: in the words of the University’s mission statement::: “the formation of an authentic human community graced by the Spirit of Christ.”

https://go.nd.edu/WalktheWalk

“Sebastian Treese’s work is a testament to the fact that it is possible to design imaginatively and still seamlessly build within the context of a rich cultural heritage. His buildings enrich the urban settings where they are constructed::: and upon reflection it is clear that they are imbued with a rich understanding of historical precedent.”

Sebastian Treese::: a leader in the process of current architectural renewal in Germany::: has been named the recipient of the 2021 Richard H. Driehaus Prize.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Sebastian Treese named 2021 Richard H. Driehaus Prize laureate

As most of the country awaits their turn in line to receive a coronavirus vaccine::: some have questions about its safety::: how it was developed::: and what it means for life after the vaccination.

The ND Stories podcast talked with Dr. Mark Mulligan '80::: an infectious disease expert and head of NYU’s Langone Vaccine Center. Dr. Mulligan has worked on vaccine trials for decades::: including most recently::: the vaccine for COVID-19.

"The vaccines have been shown to be safe and highly effective. And you'll be not only protecting yourself::: but you'll be protecting those around you who may not be able to respond to vaccines or not protected by the vaccines. It really is an important act for yourself::: but equally important for those around you."

Listen: https://go.nd.edu/b9e574

NEWS.ND.EDU
Notre Dame Stories: Developing a COVID-19 Vaccine
column3: Do we have to get the vaccine every year or are we one and done?

column1:
Notre Dame Admissions will continue with a test-optional policy for the 2022 and 2023 application years. First-year and transfer applicants will not be required to submit standardized test scores as part of their application for undergraduate admission.

The test-optional policy allows students to choose whether to submit a test score to be included in the evaluation of their application. The goal is to empower students to decide what they consider to be the strongest application to put forward to Notre Dame.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Notre Dame will continue test-optional policy for 2022 and 2023 application years
column3:
ND is not alone in this - many schools have already announced they will be test optional for the 2022 application year and I expect more will follow. Some of the other schools include: Harvard::: Northwestern::: Amherst::: Stanford::: Brown::: Boston College::: all University of California schools. The SAT and ACT are struggling to stay relevant. These schools can fill their classes several times over with kids who have perfect scores. Grades::: course rigor::: extracurricular
s::: community service::: recommendations
::: personal essays - all paint a much broader and more accurate picture of candidates than a single test score that given enough time and money can be improved upon.
column4: It would seem that with a test-optional policy that there is necessarily no consistent objective standard. Potentially every application is without an objective benchmark making the selection process completely subjective if not potentially arbitrary. I can understand the desire to have some subjectivity in the selection process to address “special cases” but shouldn’t there be some objective marker that serves as a tie-breaker if nothing else?
column5: While many may feel this is a negative::: in truth it is a positive. Over the course of the year::: many students have signed up multiple times in an attempt to take the SAT or ACT::: only to be turned away as the testing sites cancelled. These students::: my own child being one of them::: studied for months to ready themselves and were devastated and worried this would impact their chances at scholarships and college admittance. There are currently many universities that have taken the test optional approach::: even prior to the pandemic. One such example is the University of Chicago. I applaud Notre Dame for incorporating this policy. They are truly taking a holistic approach in the application process. I believe ND admissions will continue to accept the best and brightest students in the world regardless of going test-optional. Go Irish!🍀
column6:
With a high school senior daughter accepted to Wake Forest which has been test optional for years::: we are very aware of the policy. There’s a reason so many schools (the Ivies were among the first) are moving to test optional::: which the pandemic only accelerated because most tests were canceled. Standardized tests alone have little correlation with college performance or performance afterwards. There is ample data out there now at the schools that have been test optional for years comparing students that submit test scores and students that don’t::: and there is no difference in performance. What everyone is realizing is that as a standalone the test is not a good predictor of success in college::: that there are better ways to evaluate an applicant in a more holistic way. Simply::: students that have high test scores but don’t have a super strong application otherwise are not as strong as students that have strong applications otherwise regardless of the test score.

And yes I was a bit bummed that the daughter of a proud Notre Dame grad chose to not go to Notre Dame! But I took her there in the winter to make sure she understood what winters were like and she hated it

“For many years::: it has been my honor to join with Notre Dame students::: faculty::: staff::: alumni and friends at the annual March for Life. Though the march is virtual this year::: let us continue our witness to the sanctity of every human life and reject in all its expressions what Pope Francis has called a ‘throwaway culture.’ - Rev. John I. Jenkins::: C.S.C.

In addition to the many ways our University community has and will commemorate the annual March for Life::: we join with all who strive to build a culture of life through the following expressions of prayer:

- On Friday::: Mass will be celebrated at 11:30 a.m. EST in the Basilica of the Sacred Heart for the sanctity of human life. View the livestream: https://go.nd.edu/BasilicaLivestream
- Following Mass::: the Basilica of the Sacred Heart’s bells will toll as an audible expression of our community’s commitment to the sanctity of all human life.
- All students::: faculty::: staff::: alumni and friends are also invited to join Father Gerry Olinger::: C.S.C.::: vice president for mission engagement and church affairs::: in praying a virtual Rosary for Life for the intention of increased commitment to the profound dignity of human life: https://go.nd.edu/RosaryforLife2020

Mosquera was able to receive his visa and plans to make it to campus in time for the spring 2021 semester. He and other international students' stories offer a glimpse into the reality of being an international student during a global pandemic: https://go.nd.edu/ASemesterInterrupted

ND.EDU
A Semester::: Interrupted: International Student Stories

When Notre Dame bestowed an honorary degree on Hank Aaron in 2005::: the citation referenced his legendary baseball career and concluded that::: most importantly::: he had done it all ‘fair and square.’ His many records::: particularly in the face of racial prejudice::: make him one of the greats of the game.

For as marvelous as his skills were::: his off-the-field accomplishments were just as — perhaps even more — important and long-lasting. During his playing days and throughout his life::: he played a quiet but important role in the civil rights movement and for racial justice. Part of that commitment included his and his wife Billye’s Chasing the Dream Foundation::: which for 25 years has helped young people with limited financial resources pursue their dreams. We were honored four years ago when the foundation’s 44th scholarship — in recognition of Mr. Aaron’s uniform number — was established at Notre Dame.

Hank Aaron was a tremendous baseball player and an even better human being. The prayers of the Notre Dame family are with Billye and his family::: friends and many fans.

Weiss::: originally from Rio de Janeiro::: Brazil::: recently completed a semester abroad in Rome in the study away locally program. The program was created to accommodate the hundreds of international students unable to get to campus due to the global suspension of visa processing and entry restrictions and allowed them to be fully enrolled at Notre Dame and remain academically engaged.

column76: As a Notre Dame alum::: I pray that most of those commenting on this post are not affiliated with my University. What happened on Wednesday was an affront to our Constitution::: a violent siege meant to cause harm against our elected officials::: and it was based on a egregious lie fomented by this President. There is no equivalence to any other event. Moreover::: it was antithetical to Catholic teaching and the mission of Notre Dame. Notre Dame condemns ALL violence::: always::: but we were also taught to engage in peaceful debate rooted in facts and to have respect and compassion for everyone. And to the parents above whose son is thinking of applying::: most of my ND alum friends are centrist or progressive and are appalled at what happened last week. Please do not dissuade your son from applying::: because it is a great school with great people. Kudos to Father Jenkins for his statement.

column24:
Dear 2020:::

Today I bid you farewell. You kneecapped me a few times::: but you also embedded marvelous memories deep within my heart.

For example::: the memory of my last hug with another human on 3/22/20. It was a playful::: joyful hug with a laughing::: three-year-old little girl as we played with her toy cars. (Her yellow Corvette overtook and totaled my red Mustang.)

The deep feelings of accomplishment and marvel as I watched the growth of the spindly little flowers that I planted in my flower boxes last Spring.

By the end of June::: they’d burst forth in wild abandon. Their cacophony of colors and scents many times brought tears of joy to my eyes as I lounged on my porch::: enjoying the color coordinated sunset.

Somehow::: those flowers and the colors of the evening skies magnified each other’s beauty::: as if they were lovers::: sharing a tender “good night”.

Oh. And the walks on the beaches. The sheer volume of odd and beautiful agates that I came across. It was as if Ocean pushed her gentle waves up to my feet and then slowly retreated::: leaving handfuls of beautiful treasures right where I stood.

You allowed me to have a last conversation with someone extraordinarily
dear to me::: Sr. Elaine DesRosiers::: two days before she died from COVID-19 on 12/16/20. It was a kind of a miracle::: actually. She was hooked up to so many machines that were helping her to breathe. Sometimes::: it was really hard to hear her over the mechanical sounds::: but she was lucid. She was forward thinking (She reminded me that she owes me a painting.) We reminisced about the past 40 years. We laughed A LOT!

All in all::: 2020::: you’ve been most beautiful and kind. I just wanted to say::: “thank you”.

column1:
O come::: let us adore Him! With full heart and voice::: we come together to proclaim the birth of Jesus!

This collaborative arrangement of “Oh Come::: All Ye Faithful” features traditional::: Latino::: and Gospel sacred music performed by the following Campus Ministry choirs: Coro Primavera::: The University of Notre Dame Folk Choir::: Notre Dame Liturgical Choir::: Notre Dame Magnificat Choir ::: and Voices of Faith Gospel Choir. Each of the 80 student voices you hear were recorded separately and stitched together by our directors along with additional instruments.

As we unify our voices this Christmas season::: let us proclaim the coming of Jesus who brings us light in the darkness!

column1:
Tonight::: December 21::: Jupiter and Saturn will appear from Earth to be overlapping each other::: almost looking as if they are one bright::: shining object in the winter sky.

This extraordinary and unusual alignment of the two largest planets in our solar system last occurred in 1623. Notre Dame astrophysicist Grant Matthews believes this same planetary alignment on April 17::: 6 B.C.::: along with other factors::: is the best explanation for the star of Bethlehem::: heralding the birth of Jesus.

ND.EDU
Royal Beauty Bright
column3:
Am I understanding correctly?
The Star of Bethlehem appeared 6 years before the birth of Jesus Christ and lasted until He was born?
So::: there was nothing extraordinary about The Star that ended up being Saturn and Jupiter overlapping?
column4: Wrong sky. Frankly::: I'm surprised that people are comparing the two events. To the naked eye::: at sunset::: in the "western" sky::: it's really not that spectacular::: not even what I can imagine what was witnessed those::: who were there::: thousands of years ago::: in the "eastern" sky...

column1:
Rev. Gregory A. Green::: C.S.C.::: a Holy Cross priest who served the University of Notre Dame and the Congregation of Holy Cross in multiple roles for more than a half-century::: died Tuesday::: December 15::: at Holy Cross House::: across St. Joseph’s Lake from his beloved alma mater. He was 85.

Father Green’s many and varied roles at Notre Dame included rector of Sorin Hall::: associate vice president of student affairs from 1977 to 1984::: and priest in residence at Sorin::: Siegfried and Welsh Family halls. He was most widely known to the broad campus community as the longtime staff chaplain::: ministering to the spiritual needs of Notre Dame employees from 1988 to 2013.

NEWS.ND.EDU
In memoriam: Rev. Gregory A. Green::: C.S.C.::: longtime staff chaplain::: priest-in-residence at Notre Dame
column3: Rest In Peace Father Greg. I have such wonderful memories of Sunday night Mass at Siegfried Hall. You were such a wonderful priest and I always appreciated your message. We always knew you were there if we needed you. I also remember you cheering on our Hall football team every week!
column4: Fr. Greg was such a big part of what made Siegfried home when I was at ND. He was such a kind::: gentle and generous soul::: who cared deeply about his flock. I loved working with him and serving on the liturgical commission for Siegfried. Rest in Peace::: Fr. Greg::: and may Perpetual Light shine upon you.
column5: Fr. Green was a classmate of my Dad's at the Holy Cross High School Seminary program. I got to know him myself at Wednesday night Mass at Lewis Hall. He was a dear friend. May he Rest in Peace.
column6: He was a wonderful priest and a wonderful man. He was truly adored by his niece and nephews. May he rest in peace.
column7: Rest in peace::: Father Green.
column8: Father Greg was one of the kindest::: most compassionate souls I've had the good fortune to know. My memories in Siegfried would not have been the same without him. May he rest in eternal peace.
column9: Rest in Peace::: Father Green. He was a wonderful advisor to friends going through difficult times. I also remember him from my days at Corby Hall.
column10: I was one of the ARs in Welsh Family when Fr. Greg was in residence 😢 Rest In Peace
column11: Rest in peace Fr. Greg::: I have many memories of you::: always am uplifting word and a kind soul.
column12: Fr. Green was a very kind man who was a cheerful and supportive presence. Sympathies to his dear family and the entire Notre Dame community. 💕🙏🏻
column13: RIP Father Greg.
column14: Such a kind::: serving priest. Rest In Peace Fr. Green🙏🏻
column15: So Sorry for Your Loss::: God Bless Father Green.
column16: A kind and gentle soul. He always greeted you with a “welcome home” when visiting campus long after graduation. He made life in Siegfried Hall even that much better. Rest In Peace::: Fr. Green.
column17: My heart breaks that I didn’t get to say goodbye and hear him call me Smitty one last time. He was a wonderful and holy priest. Loved visiting with him and serving on the liturgy committee during my years in Siegfried. May he rest in eternal peace.
column18: Rest in peace Father Green. He was such a great friend to my parents. He officiated my wedding and baptized both of my children. You will be missed. ❤
column19: My heart is breaking. Fr. Green baptized my twin grandsons and was there for my husband's burial service. Rest in peace Father. You will be missed by all. 😥🙏❤
column20: Fr. Green also was in residence at Alumni Hall. I last saw him at Fr. Heppen’s funeral. I don’t get back to campus very often and it was comforting to hear Fr. Green’s greeting “welcome home.”
column21: What a kind and gentle man. May he rest in peace.
column22: Father Greg was a wonderful and kind man. He was such an important part of Siegfried Hall and such a friendly person! He will be missed!❤️☘️
column23: I have wonderful memories of this man. His kindness::: compassion and service to others is remembered today. ❤️🙏.
column24: Fr. Greg never (ever) missed a Siegfried Slammer Sunday night interhall football game. Kindest man! Married my husband and I. Such a big loss! May the perpetual light shine on him forever .
column25: Rest In Peace::: Father Greg ❤️🍀 Welsh Fam was lucky to have you.

column27: I didn't know this man::: but I hope he is at rest in heaven. May his family find peace and healing.

column30: Rest In Peace Fr. Greg. Thank you for making Welsh Fam felt like home for our daughter (ND’17 ‘19).

Given the current health and safety guidelines regarding the coronavirus pandemic::: the Basilica of the Sacred Heart will offer an adjusted Mass schedule for all 2020 Christmas Masses.

Masses on Christmas Eve will be offered at 4::: 7 and 10 p.m.::: and Mass on Christmas Day will be offered at 10 a.m. All three Christmas Eve Masses will be livestreamed.

To accommodate as many people as possible in a safe manner::: a reservation will be required. The reservation request form will open at 9 a.m. EST Monday::: December 14::: and close at noon EST Wednesday::: December 16. You can make your reservation here: CampusMinistry.nd.edu/Christmas.
