column1:
When firefighters run into a burning building::: they know the dangers associated with their job. But Notre Dame professor Graham Peaslee's research suggests firefighters are at risk before they ever leave the firehouse.

Last year::: we showed you how he has found alarming amounts of PFAS in firefighter gear. These chemicals have been linked to elevated rates of cancer.

Learn more about how we're fighting to protect the brave and catch this spot as it reairs during tomorrow's football game: https://go.nd.edu/96277a
column3:
We could not be more grateful to Dr Peaslee for his study.::: and not only his study.::: but he is challenging the dialogue that manufacturers are feeding firefighters that despite the thousands of studies on the harms of PFAS::: and despite the known science from the C-8 Science Panel::: that the PFOA in their gear for 20 years is safe.::: Dr Peaslee is in the firehouses and fire service zoom meetings::: and pre COVID-19 was visiting firefighters to teach them.

Stunning that his teaching goes far past the halls of your magnificent University of Notre Dame

column1:
A new study conducted by researchers from Notre Dame::: University of South Florida and University of Wisconsin-Madison::: suggests that global warming is likely to increase the disease risk for animals worldwide.

The study supports a phenomenon known as “thermal mismatch hypothesis:::” which is the idea that the greatest risk for infectious disease in cold climate-adapted animals – such as polar bears – occurs as temperatures rise::: while the risk for animals living in warmer climates occurs as temperatures fall.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Global warming likely to increase disease risk for animals worldwide

At 6:03 p.m.::: Nov. 21::: Notre Dame sophomore Lucas Hopkins could look to the sky from his family’s home southeast of Houston and watch his father fly overhead.

Just four minutes later::: his dad::: U.S. Air Force Col. Michael Hopkins::: flew over the Notre Dame campus.

Time flies when you’re speeding 250 miles above planet Earth at 17:::500 miles per hour aboard the International Space Station.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Sophomore Lucas Hopkins can look up – literally – to his dad
column3: That must be an awesome experience for that lucky young man . . . along with him::: we're so proud of his dad!🍀🇺🇸🙏💖
column4: That is awesome! On a much smaller scale::: my next to youngest son flew over ND stadium while I was at the spring game. They tilted the wings and flashed the lights so I new it was him. We will always remember that day::: we were so proud of him. Unfortunately we lost him in a trucking accident in Florida 3 years ago.
column5: I was an ND student for two launches of my father on the space shuttle in 1988 and 1990. Was surreal to be sure and hope it was as exciting and cool for Lucas as it was for me. Still remember an epic party we had in Alumni Hall where my engineering friend Rich Shank rigged a phone to a stereo so we could talk with my dad while he was in quarantine at Kennedy Space Center in the days before launch. Imagine 40 students crammed into a room “interviewing” my father after a few hours of revelry! Still one of my best ND memories!

Law Professor Emeritus Thomas F. Broden Jr. — a pioneer in clinical legal education and a skilled advocate for civil rights and the indigent — died Nov. 20 at his home in South Bend. He was 96.

Broden joined the Notre Dame Law School faculty in 1950 and served the University::: the South Bend community and the U.S. government in numerous ways.

His long list of accomplishments includes playing an integral role in the creation of the U.S. Civil Rights Commission in 1956. As counsel to the U.S. House of Representatives Judiciary Committee::: he was the staff attorney-in-charge of the first civil rights bill since the post-Civil War Reconstruction Era.

NEWS.ND.EDU
In Memoriam: Thomas F. Broden::: emeritus professor of law

column1:
Advanced Diagnostics and Therapeutics::: a research center at Notre Dame::: has become the Institute for Precision Health (IPH).

Precision health is an approach to biomedicine that seeks to prevent and treat disease and promote wellness by understanding human variability at the molecular and cellular levels::: especially in the context of each person’s unique environment. The IPH aims to invent tools and collect and analyze data that enable the delivery of life-enhancing diagnostic::: prognostic::: and therapeutic capabilities to each individual.

SCIENCE.ND.EDU
Notre Dame announces the Institute for Precision Health

column5: "The Golden Boy" won the Heisman Trophy in 1956::: the only player from a losing team ever to win the trophy. Many consider Hornung the greatest all-around football player in Notre Dame history. In the 1956 season::: he led his team offensively in passing::: rushing::: scoring::: kickoff and punt returns::: and punting. He also played defense and led his team in passes broken up and was second in interceptions and tackles made. And he was an excellent place kicker.

column1:
Since World War II::: Notre Dame has been at the forefront of radiation research helping to make advancements in medicine::: energy::: and space.

Today::: Physic professor Jay LaVerne is working with a team to design new polymers to create lighter::: less cumbersome and more radiation-resistant space suits.

He also hopes to try irradiating medications::: seeds and other necessities for astronauts who intend to go to space for extended periods of time. Without those essentials::: the length of missions could be severely limited.

FIGHTINGFOR.ND.EDU
Fighting to Reach the Next Frontier in Space // What Would You Fight For? // University of Notre Dame

column1:
Scientists have long believed that the brain protects itself from an aggressive immune response to keep down inflammation. However::: researchers at Notre Dame have discovered that this evolutionary control may work against it when a cancer cell attempts to spread to the brain.

Researchers showed that one type of cell important for immunity::: called a myeloid cell::: can suppress the immune response — which has the effect of allowing breast cancer cells to metastasize to the brain to form secondary tumor cells there.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Cancer cells mediate immune suppression in the brain

I used to sing in the Chapel Choir (nka the Notre Dame Liturgical Choir) back in the early 1980's.

I've witnessed how the Folk Choir has evolved since I was there.

The Folk Choir has become what Sue-Seid Martin set out for the original Chapel Choir::: Patricia Klepper::: Joe Aiu::: Ed Darr::: June Giroux Rzepczynski. They're doing music she was specifically prevented or blocked from presenting when she was director.

Congratulations
to the ND Folk Choir for achieving her dream and mission::: integrating a choir w/ male and newly admitted FEMALE voices::: while blending the music traditions of the old mass into what was then the relatively new mass now being celebrated in the vernacular::: introducing both classic choral works and modern::: QUALITY new music::: and expanded hymnody into the liturgy.

We mourn the passing of first-year students Valeria Espinel::: from Guayaquil::: Ecuador::: and Olivia Laura Rojas::: from Santa Cruz de la Sierra::: Bolivia::: who died this morning after being struck by an automobile.

A third student remains hospitalized::: and we pray for his family and his recovery.

We will come together as a campus community this evening for a prayer service at 8 p.m. in front of Bond Hall. Please wear a mask and practice physical distancing as we pray for Valeria::: Olivia::: their families::: and all who loved them.

Counseling and Campus Ministry support are available for classmates and others affected by this tragedy.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Notre Dame mourns the deaths of two students

column1:
A digital image of a famous piece of art doesn’t tend to stir the soul in the same way as looking at it while standing in the same room. The context matters.

Theology and psychology faculty will explore this idea in an 18-month research project exploring the ways in which viewing art informs and enhances spiritual growth and how that changes based on time and place. Their findings could help churches and museums shape messaging and offer more powerful encounters with paintings and sculptures.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Interdisciplinary study by Notre Dame theology and psychology faculty explores link between art and spiritual understanding

column1:
Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of Chicago runs the city's Homeless Prevention Call Center and has helped thousands of families stay off the streets::: but Catholic Charities knows funding for public programs is never guaranteed::: so it wanted to prove its method was cost effective and impactful.

They approached the Wilson Sheehan Lab for Economic Opportunities - LEO - at Notre Dame to assess if the emergency financial assistance they provide through the call-in line helps prevent homelessness.

LEO found that the financial assistance made recipients 76 percent less likely to become homeless::: and kept more than 700 children off the Chicago streets. Now other cities across the country are using Notre Dame’s work to inform their own strategies on homelessness prevention: https://go.nd.edu/WWYFFHomelessness

column1:
On average::: an estimated three out of every 1:::000 newborns will suffer a brachial plexus injury during birth::: damaging the bundle of nerves that connect the brain and spinal cord to the shoulders::: arms and hands. Once the connection between the nerves and the spinal cord is torn::: it cannot be repaired.

But new research from Biological Science professor Cody Smith's lab involving a chemotherapy treatment administered shortly after injury shows that regeneration and recovery may be possible.

See how Notre Dame is Fighting to Repair the Body: https://go.nd.edu/RepairTheBody

column35:
Standards of Conduct
It is imperative that students::: faculty::: and staff call one another to accountability for lapses in mask wearing::: physical distancing::: or gathering together outside of the health and safety guidelines.

In addition to regular standards of conduct::: students involved in unsafe gatherings::: whether on or off campus::: or who display a persistent disregard for our health and safety practices in academic or campus settings may be referred to the University conduct process. Unsafe gatherings include those where masks are not worn and/or large numbers over 20 are gathered with disregard for physical distancing guidelines.

Community members::: whether students::: faculty::: or staff::: should report unsafe behavior with specific addresses::: names::: and details. Depending on the nature of the incident::: hosts of unsafe gatherings jeopardize their ability to remain a part of the University community.

How are popular culture and translanguaging -- the idea that there are multiple linguistic registers used in students’ everyday lives -- impacting U.S. classrooms?

Ernest Morrell is expanding literacy education research at Notre Dame and exploring these important topics.

“We don’t want to throw really good research into the noise:::” Morrell said. “But we do want to be ready because these are real answers for people — especially the digital literacies — that speak very poignantly to this moment of remote learning.”

column1:
Judge Amy Coney Barrett::: professor of law and a 1997 graduate of Notre Dame Law School::: was nominated today to the Supreme Court of the United States.

She is the first Notre Dame graduate and faculty member to be nominated to serve on the nation’s highest court.

“The same impressive intellect::: character and temperament that made Judge Barrett a successful nominee for the U.S. Court of Appeals will serve her and the nation equally well as a Justice of the United States Supreme Court:::” Notre Dame President Rev. John I. Jenkins::: C.S.C.::: said. “An alumna and a faculty member of Notre Dame Law School::: Judge Barrett has epitomized the University’s commitment to teaching::: scholarship::: justice and service to society. She is a person of the utmost integrity who::: as a jurist::: acts first and foremost in accord with the law. I join her colleagues in the Law School and across the campus in congratulating her on the nomination::: and wish her and her family well through what has become::: sadly::: a personally bruising confirmation process.”

NEWS.ND.EDU
Notre Dame Law School Professor Barrett nominated to US Supreme Court

column1:
Fr. Jenkins announced plans to begin the 2021 spring semester with in-person classes Feb. 3::: forgo spring break and end classes May 11::: this morning.

As with the Fall Semester::: we will not have a spring break. There will be no classes on Good Friday::: April 2::: and we will offer special opportunities for students to celebrate Easter on campus.

Final exams will be held on May 14::: 15 and 17-19::: with reading days for exams on May 12::: 13 and 16.

Commencement weekend will be May 22-23.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Notre Dame’s spring semester to begin Feb. 3

Architecture professor Michael Lykoudis and a group of fifth-year students traveled to Mati::: Greece::: twice in 2019 to assess the damage of a 2018 wildfire and design a plan to rebuild.

The students determined some of the priorities to build a resilient community included a fire defense perimeter::: enhanced access to the beach with lighting::: new fire alert and fighting systems::: bells and a tall clock tower to point people to safety in reduced visibility::: and new streets to prevent traffic jams.

Fighting for Resilient Communities // What Would You Fight For? // University of Notre Dame

column31:
Gospel LK 8:4-15

When a large crowd gathered::: with people from one town after another
journeying to Jesus::: he spoke in a parable.
“A sower went out to sow his seed.
And as he sowed::: some seed fell on the path and was trampled:::
and the birds of the sky ate it up.
Some seed fell on rocky ground::: and when it grew:::
it withered for lack of moisture.
Some seed fell among thorns:::
and the thorns grew with it and choked it.
And some seed fell on good soil::: and when it grew:::
it produced fruit a hundredfold.”
After saying this::: he called out:::
“Whoever has ears to hear ought to hear.”
Then his disciples asked him
what the meaning of this parable might be.
He answered:::
“Knowledge of the mysteries of the Kingdom of God
has been granted to you;
but to the rest::: they are made known through parables
so that they may look but not see::: and hear but not understand.
“This is the meaning of the parable.
The seed is the word of God.
Those on the path are the ones who have heard:::
but the Devil comes and takes away the word from their hearts
that they may not believe and be saved.
Those on rocky ground are the ones who::: when they hear:::
receive the word with joy::: but they have no root;
they believe only for a time and fall away in time of temptation.
As for the seed that fell among thorns:::
they are the ones who have heard::: but as they go along:::
they are choked by the anxieties and riches and pleasures of life:::
and they fail to produce mature fruit.
But as for the seed that fell on rich soil:::
they are the ones who::: when they have heard the word:::
embrace it with a generous and good heart:::
and bear fruit through perseverance.”

column1:
A Statement from Fr. Jenkins on the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg:

“As we mourn the passing of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg::: I recall fondly her standing-room-only appearance in the Joyce Center in 2016. Combining intellectual rigor with playfulness and candor::: Justice Ginsburg discussed policy::: politics and the struggle for women to find their rightful place in the administration of justice. It was a personal privilege for me to take her on a tour of campus and witness her kindness and courtesy to everyone she met.

“Upon the death of her close friend and ideological opposite::: the late Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia::: Justice Ginsburg wrote a fitting epitaph for all who serve the law so well: ‘Toward the end of the opera Scalia/Ginsburg::: tenor Scalia and soprano Ginsburg sing a duet: “We are different::: we are one:::” different in our interpretation of written texts::: one in our reverence for the Constitution and the institution we serve.'”

column72:
#Repost @marthaplimpton

・・・
Because of her::: when I turned 18 I could apply for and receive a credit card without a male signatory. Because of her::: when I bought my house::: I could apply for a mortgage without being married and without having a male co-sign. Because of her::: I could be called to do my civic duty and serve on a jury without being exempted on a count of being a woman. Because of her I grew up believing I had a claim to my personhood as an equally vested citizen of my country. These changes happened in my own lifetime. And yet::: my whole growing up::: so deeply effected by her efforts::: I never knew it was because of her and the countless clerks and lawyers she worked with arguing six of the most critical cases affecting women and families the Supreme Court had yet heard. She changed this country for women. For EVERYONE. Because women's rights are HUMAN RIGHTS. Because of her::: I realized my own potential as a professional::: a homeowner::: a person with credit::: with assets::: with independence. My thanks to this woman are inexpressible. No matter where you begin::: where you land is still::: potentially::: unknown. This devotion of hers to equality::: not just to "being equal" but to the concept of equality as a dynamic and not a fixed standard::: made her one of the most consequential legal and cultural minds of the 20th and 21st centuries. She's my hero. Thank you::: Justice Ginsburg::: for everything. #RBG #BECAUSEOFHER #womensrightsare
humanrights #justiceginsburg #thankyou #thankabravewoma
ntoday and then #VOTE #fight #doitforruth

column1:
When a wildfire brokeout in Mati::: Greece::: in the midst of a heatwave in 2018::: Architecture professor Michael Lykoudis sprang into action. In 2019::: he took a group of fifth-year architecture students to the seaside town to assess the damage and determine how to improve the town’s resiliency in the face of future emergencies::: while keeping its beauty and traditional architecture.

Today::: as deadly fires burn millions of acres across the western United States::: American communities will also need to make changes in order to prevent future dangers.

“I was moved to assist the people of Mati in their time of need::: but recent events have shown us that wildfires are an increasing threat to people around the world from Australia to California and beyond:::” Lykoudis says. “In addition to taking action to mitigate the effects of climate change::: we should reimagine vulnerable communities in ways that both enhance quality of life for the community and increase the fire resilience of the built environment.”

Learn how Notre Dame is Fighting for Resilient Communities: https://go.nd.edu/FFResilientCommunities

Compassion in medicine is more than kindness and cheerful bedside demeanor. It has four distinct components: You have to notice suffering::: be moved by it::: want to do something about it::: and act capably.

At Notre Dame::: Professor Dominic Vachon and the Hillebrand Center for Compassionate Care in Medicine at Notre Dame are applying the science of compassion to help better educate and equip doctors to withstand the trials of the job.

column1:
Notre Dame senior Sam Grewe lost his leg to osteosarcoma when he was 13 years old and spent two years undergoing chemotheraphy and treatments in hospitals. He saw first-hand the benefit physicians with a compassionate mindset have on patients::: a practice Dominic Vachon::: Director of the Hillebrand Center for Compassionate Care in Medicine at Notre Dame::: is studying as well.

Since 2011::: nearly 1:::000 students including Sam::: who is training for the Paralympic Tokyo Games and hopes to attend medical school::: have taken the Center's courses designed to teach skills such as personalism::: medical counseling and clinical ethics — the only undergraduates in the country receiving this kind of preparation.

More: https://go.nd.edu/CompassionInMedicine

column5:
I would like to follow up with Ed Devine deleting his comment to my story after I told him to stop hijacking my narrative::: he's proceeded to stalk and harass me on Facebook.

He started here::: he said I deserve all negative energy in anyone's interactions with me. I don't know if he deleted it or if the moderators did.

He has gone on to harass me on my page and wall. This is exactly the kind of behavior cis-het white men portray when minorities refuse to put up with their games.
column7:
Would be good for there to be classes to actually address being inclusive and kind to minorities. Sensitivity training for the rectresses. My freshman roommates and many other folks were atrocious. The Farley rectress literally told me to get out of my third world mentality and adopt the American college experience.

During the required health credit::: there was one session dedicated to racism and the entire period was white folks talking about how they're discriminated against by POC and it was the entire class vs me. Luckily my professors were great::: the dining hall staff and McDonald's Physical therapy were amazing.

But honestly? My experience certainly at Notre Dame was terrible because I wasn't a quiet minority just happy to be in the room. I wanted and needed respect. How did I thrive? When I was finally left alone. I did my time. I graduated. Never came back.

column10:
About 7.5% of undergrads have tested positive after going to school::: but the last week's numbers seem to indicate it is burning out.

A few questions.

1) how many of those with positive results have ended up in the hospital?

2) Is the school tracking the number of PCR replication cycles required to find a positive result?

3) If the answer to 2 is yes::: is the school correlating that information with the presence of symptoms or the lack thereof?

4) Is the school tracking the relationship between a positive student and their geographical location? In other words::: are students from hard hit states early in the pandemic such as NY::: NJ::: CT a significant factor in the outbreak?

ND players were hurt by Holtz.

In the Chicago Tribune:

Holtz must be added to a long list of disappointing white coaches (see Ditka::: Mike) and players (see Urlacher::: Brian) whose proximity to Black players and teammates did nothing to open their minds or hearts. “While Coach Lou Holtz is a former coach at Notre Dame::: his use of the University’s name at the Republican National Convention must not be taken to imply that the University endorses his views::: any candidate or any political party.

Moreover::: we Catholics should remind ourselves that while we may judge the objective moral quality of another’s actions::: we must never question the sincerity of another’s faith::: which is due to the mysterious working of grace in that person’s heart.

In this fractious time::: let us remember that our highest calling is to love.” - Notre Dame President Fr. John Jenkins on remarks by former Coach Lou Holtz at the Republican National Convention

column5:
Good morning from NY::: thank you for the updates::: but as a ND mother first and a NYC COVID ICU 2nd::: I truly believe that the first misstep of this outbreak came in the initial type of test used.
There is a higher probability of not appropriately collecting enough of a true sample with a nasal swab and it may be the underlying problem. COVID harbors deep in the nasopharyngeal cavity 😪

It is a known fact that this age group is commonly known as our asymptomatic carriers and the return to campus test should have been a nasopharyngeal not nasal.
I think that's why within 4 days of these 2 parties the spread came from undetected asymptomatic carriers.

More importantly::: the entire student body needs to be retested::: because revealing the asymptomatic carriers is imperative.

And finally and more concerning... I reached out to health services on Wednesday inquiring if the unfortunate decision is made to send the students home will they all depart the campus with a test result prior to getting in a car::: train or plane? The response...." honestly I don't have an answer to your question."
That simple question needs to be addressed sooner rather than later.

May the good Lord cradle and protect all the students and staff at ND.

column84: All the people calling for lockdowns and cancellations are no different from generals from the First World War calling for more infantry assaults across No Man's Land for four straight years no matter how many times they fail. Let's get something straight::: this virus has a survival rate of nearly 99.76%::: and even higher for college age students. The vast majority of those who have it will have no long-term side effects. To claim that this like an airborne Ebola::: or the Spanish Influenza (were the young were uniquely vulnerable and the death rate was 5-10%) or anything otherwise is nothing more than irrational unscientific panic::: and that has been clear FOR MONTHS. Second::: as the recent examples of Peru::: New Zealand::: Australia::: Japan and much of Europe reveal::: it is IMPOSSIBLE TO "DEFEAT" THE VIRUS THROUGH LOCKDOWNS. The virus will continue to circulate regardless of what we do. The virus will continue to infect people after a "nationwide" lockdown of six weeks. The virus will stay out there until herd immunity is achieved either deliberately (Sweden) or accidentally (New York City). There will never be a vaccine will 100% efficiency for the coronavirus. At best::: we will have one at 50% a year from now. We cannot hide in our basements until then. Finally::: we are not going to have a "national strategy" for this because the virus is not effecting every part of the country equally and because we are a FEDERAL Republic. Trump (who I am not voting for) does not have the power to mandate nationwide health decisions anyway. Notre Dame must resist the panic over this::: protect those who are truly vulnerable (the elderly and those with chronic health problems) and allow life and education to move on for everyone else.

I dont know how the topic went from tolerance and acceptance to ABORTION::: but ok. Let's go there. I find that most 'Christians' who oppose abortion are not even practicing Christians. Because if they were::: they wouldnt have so much hate in their hearts. Personally::: I am pro-life but I believe it should be a personal choice. I believe it is between YOU AND GOD. Free will people. Why not provide accessable birth control for all? That will reduce the # of abortions. If you are Pro-life I bet that you are probably against social programs like food stamps/
welfare. You dont want them to get abortions but yet you also dont want them to give them the tools to raise their kids. In a perfect world everyone would finish school::: get married and have children::: in that order. But we dont live in perfect world do we. If you are pro -life you SHOULD also be FOR GUN REFORM. If not::: I guess you just want to save their inevitable faith for later because chances are they will probably get killed in elementary or high school from gun voilence. Since 2017::: Notre Dame has donated 102:::622 pounds of excess food to Cultivate Food Rescue from dining::: athletics and special events::: including home football and basketball games.

Cultivate provides free::: frozen meals to primarily elementary age children via an insulated backpack program that::: before the coronavirus pandemic::: delivered 2:::400 meals per week to children in St. Joseph::: Elkhart and Marshall counties during the school year.

Hebrews 6

Revised Standard Version Catholic Edition

The Peril of Falling Away

6 Therefore let us leave the elementary doctrines of Christ and go on to maturity::: not laying again a foundation of repentance from dead works and of faith toward God::: with instruction about ablutions::: the laying on of hands::: the resurrection of the dead::: and eternal judgment. 3 And this we will do if God permits. 4 For it is impossible to restore again to repentance those who have once been enlightened::: who have tasted the heavenly gift::: and have become partakers of the Holy Spirit::: 5 and have tasted the goodness of the word of God and the powers of the age to come::: 6 if they then commit apostasy::: since they crucify the Son of God on their own account and hold him up to contempt. 7 For land which has drunk the rain that often falls upon it::: and brings forth vegetation useful to those for whose sake it is cultivated::: receives a blessing from God. 8 But if it bears thorns and thistles::: it is worthless and near to being cursed; its end is to be burned.

9 Though we speak thus::: yet in your case::: beloved::: we feel sure of better things that belong to salvation. 10 For God is not so unjust as to overlook your work and the love which you showed for his sake in serving the saints::: as you still do. 11 And we desire each one of you to show the same earnestness in realizing the full assurance of hope until the end::: 12 so that you may not be sluggish::: but imitators of those who through faith and patience inherit the promises.

What i can say with 100% certainty is that spring semester online was a joke regarding trying to learn Engineering! Glad ND is trying to make it work. column5: Is the faculty and staff being required as well? Because it makes no sense to have students tested if faculty and staff are not required.
column6:
In Asia right now where the curve has flattened::: and what I'm more interested in seeing is what policy ND has regarding contact tracing::: testing and isolation. In some ways::: the ND campus is like a country::: except that there are no border controls::: so it'll be harder to prevent community spread if anyone who's infected (and asymptomatic) starts spreading it to everyone else. To demand testing before going back to campus is a good first step::: but what are the guidelines regarding life on campus? Must masks be worn at all times::: and social distancing maintained too? What about visits to bars::: restaurants and public places in SB? and how is campus security going to enforce these rules? and let's assume something happens::: there's community spread (VERY easy to see that happening when there are people going to and fro)::: how is ND going to isolate these cases and most of all::: what about contact tracing? Is every student::: staff and faculty required to download an app and scan their mobile upon entry to every building on campus? I'm not too worried about football games since the entire season might be cancelled (the Wisconsin game's cancelled already)::: or games might be played without fans (like in Europe now)::: but if full-fledged games are permitted::: then expect community spread::: everyone who's allowed this has received bad returns worldwide. If there is community spread::: then contact tracing is vital in keeping the numbers down and everyone who's infected treated promptly and those who are not protected. Then there's the question of testing::: does ND/
SB have enough facilities and staff to ensure prompt and massive testing? and what about medical care? Do they have enough ventilators and ICUs available? and isolation stations too::: how many beds are there available? If there's a spread::: there has gotta be well-established and effective protocols available to handle it::: and then there must be curfews and all in place once a case is detected::: and once again::: how much "discipline" can admin and campus security enforce? I can't see them manhandling and rounding up anyone without a mask or keeping their dorm room doors opened::: and is mass dining in SDH and NDH allowed then? No way they're gonna be able to pull a Wuhan-styled enforcement model on campus::: but if you're lax::: then you get more cases and medical facilities get strained. I'd say its best to exercise caution given that the curve stateside hasn't flattened::: but I'm also confident the admin will take all steps necessary to protect the students::: staff and faculty on campus. This Rona bug is rather troublesome::: if you relax too much it'll come back with a vengeance::: and politics and ideology aside::: the life and safety of everyone on campus is paramount. I'd say let's hope for the best but be prepared for the worst::: so there's gotta be a solid plan in place before everyone returns.
All the best to all the returning students::: Go Irish!

Our hysteria stems from the accumulation of yet another set of arbitrary guidelines not targeted at interventions for highly vulnerable populations but set to control your impulse to resume individual initiative in protecting human life and livelihoods.

The Tri-Campus community should be focusing on resources to make remote learning better::: NOT forcing students to become exposed to a deadly virus. It's appalling for students::: staff::: and faculty.

column1:
"We embrace our visitors. We don't chase them away."

A letter from Fr. Jenkins to Acting Secretary of Homeland Security Chad F. Wolf on international students and scholars: https://go.nd.edu/c20e8a

The University will also file an amicus brief in support of a court motion by Harvard University and MIT to prevent the expulsion of international students who are enrolled exclusively online: https://go.nd.edu/1943ee
column3: Understandably challenging times can create a more fluid approach::: the mere idea of attempting to dispatch students elsewhere when they have been here since the outbreak started is clearly not thinking farther than the doorway. No deporting needed as they can commence online classes at any point safely and perhaps enjoy limited "treasure or scavenger hunting" in the library::: local museum::: or just about town for engagement. I participated in a QR code hunt myself as part of a fundraiser and only saw one other member of the club.

🇺🇸👇🇺🇸🌷🇺🇸👇🇺🇸
O decision makers::: leaders of the humans and their people altogether in various regions::: I exhort you only to one thing that you rise-up forGod’s sake by twos and singly::: then ponder who is the one that God fulfilled to him the challenge with Truth upon the actual reality in regard to what they call it coronavirus? Is it the challenge of the human physicians or the challenge of the Awaited Mahdi servant of God and His khalifa the Imam Mahdi Nasser Mohammad Al-Yemeni?

That’s in order for you to know the sure knowledge that by no means and they can never encompass knowledge from Allah except by what He pleases; glory be to Him above what you associate (with Him) and apostate because of what you have from modern science have deceived and (Allah) encompassed you with what the ancient ones did not have::: then what you have from science of the technical data and the knowledge in various fields have deceived you::: for that (Allah) challenged you by what you do not encompass knowledge and from the tiniest soldiers of Allah until He made your data zero on the left (has no value) O community of whom they rejoiced with what they have of knowledge and they thought that they indeed have power over everything then Allah insulted your ability and humiliated your arrogance and removed your conceitedness by the smallest soldier from His creation; not seen by the naked eye for its small size and that’s in order for you to know the worth of yourselves::: as well in order for you to know the sure knowledge that Allah’s chastisement; the strangling disease of what you call it coronavirus that could never remove it from you other than Allah::: Him Alone. Verily::: they must repent from the major sins::: indecencies::: oppressing people and the wrongfulness of association::: and to say: “Our Lord::: we have wronged ourselves::: if You do not forgive us and (not) have mercy on us we certainly would be of the losers”. And after the repent let them say: “Oh Allah::: I am Your servant::: I ask you by the fact there is no God except You::: and by the fact of Your mercy that You ordained upon YourSelf::: and by the fact of greatness of the Bliss of YourSelf’s good-pleasure that is greater than the bliss of Your heavenly-garden
that you heal me from the chastisement of corona or remove it away from me surely I believe in the true caller from You. Oh Allah::: remove Your chastisement away from us and from every entrance so we would follow the path of Truth from You::: and to make us steadfast on fulfilling what we promised You — O Who comes between man and his heart::: surely we do not have except Your mercy that You ordained upon YourSelf. Indeed::: if You do not forgive us and (not) have mercy on us we would surely be of the losers. Oh our Allah::: You have said in Your decisive Book: {And your Lord says: Pray to Me::: I will answer you.}Truthful Allah the Great [Ghãfer] 40:60::: so from me is the supplication and turning (close) yet from You is to responding::: indeed you You never violate Your promise::: our Lord::: glory be to You::: Surely Your promise is ever True and You are the Most Merciful than all who have mercy. O our Allah::: make us steadfast upon fulfilling what we promised You to follow Allah’s global caller khalifa of Allah in the land; the Imam Mahdi Nasser Mohammad Al-Yemeni. O our Allah::: make sending him as favor on us and not affliction against us because we turned away from his true call (to Allah); for the Imam Mahdi Nasser Mohammad Al-Yemeni”.

column11:
The reason that Allah challenged you by the tiniest of His creatures from the minor chastisement; that’s because of your turn away and the arrogance of enemies of Allah among you who are into pride in the land and deviate from Allah’s religion and His Book the grand Quran::: so they thought that they are the undefeated power::: and they want to put off Allah’s light::: so He challenged them initially with the hidden tiniest of His soldiers::: unseen for its minute size fashioned in the Book::: it lives in various climates in severe cold::: in severe hot and in moderate climate::: a miracle from Allah. It lives in all seasons of earth latitude and longitude; a new living creature and a new parable from the species of tiniest-creatur
es. O children of Adam::: in fact it is blood tiniest-creatur
e from its minutest size::: that is chastisement of evil-plague in the Book by which Allah subjected pharaoh and his soldiers::: tiny in its size yet great in its annihilation::: in fact it is most damaging than the flood::: locust::: bugs and frogs; in fact it is blood disease directly inflicts children of Adam from the minor chastisement to those who turn away from the Book::: and we do not show them a sign but it is bigger than its sister::: and it is similar signs differ in annihilation and infliction by which Allah aided every prophet::: so He inflicted their folks from the minor chastisement. Allah’s prophets said to them an evil-plague has fallen upon you from your Lord and it is from the minor chastisement before the major chastisement for you may return so you call on Allah::: Him Alone::: begging and humble from the humiliation then they promised their Lord to follow caller of the Truth from their Lord to remove away from them what inflicted them of harm::: so Allah responded to them and removed what they have of harm then He commanded His soldiers that occupy against them in their land to leave their land and Allah healed them::: but unfortunately::: after they been healed of what inflicted them they said: It is mere pandemic has inflicted our forefathers before and they were healed from it before us. And Allah the Most High said: {And We did not send a prophet to a town but We seized its people with distress and affliction that they might plead (humbling themselves).(94
) Then We changed the evil for good::: till they became affluent and said: Distress and happiness did indeed touch our fathers. So We took them by surprise while they perceived not.(95)}Truthf
ul Allah the Great [Al-A`arãf] 7:94-95
{وَمَاۤ أَرۡسَلۡنَا فِی قَرۡیَةٍ مِّن نَّبِیٍّ إِلَّاۤ أَخَذۡنَاۤ أَهۡلَهَا بِٱلۡبَأۡسَاۤءِ
وَٱلضَّرَّاۤءِ لَعَلَّهُمۡ یَضَّرَّعُونَ ۝ ثُمَّ بَدَّلۡنَا مَكَانَ ٱلسَّیِّئَةِ ٱلۡحَسَنَةَ حَتَّىٰ عَفَوا۟ وَّقَالُوا۟ قَدۡ مَسَّ ءَابَاۤءَنَا ٱلضَّرَّاۤءُ وَٱلسَّرَّاۤءُ فَأَخَذۡنَـٰهُم
بَغۡتَةً وَهُمۡ لَا یَشۡعُرُونَ} صدق الله العظيم[سورة الأعراف 94 - 95].

In fact::: it is from levels of the minor chastisement::: for each are levels of what they did but most people do not know::: would Allah inflict them with this but as warning to them so Allah would not annihilate them by the major chastisement altogether while they are ungrateful-disb
elievers? But unfortunately::: after they pleaded to their Lord humbly crying (Allah) had mercy for them and removed what befell them::: then lo! They broke their covenant and their hearts hardened after the pleading and humbling! And Allah the Most High said: {And indeed We sent (messengers) to nations before you then We seized them with distress and affliction that they might humble themselves.(42)
Yet why did they not::: when Our punishment came to them::: humble themselves? But their hearts hardened and satan made all that they did seem fair to them.(43) Then::: when they neglected that with which they had been admonished::: We opened for them the gates of all things. Until::: when they rejoiced in that which they were given::: We seized them suddenly; then lo! they were in utter despair.(44)}Tr
uthful Allah the Great [Al-An`ãm] 6:42-44
{وَلَقَدۡ أَرۡسَلۡنَاۤ إِلَىٰۤ أُمَمٍ مِّن قَبۡلِكَ فَأَخَذۡنَـٰهُم
بِٱلۡبَأۡسَاۤءِ
وَٱلضَّرَّاۤءِ لَعَلَّهُمۡ یَتَضَرَّعُونَ ۝ فَلَوۡلَاۤ إِذۡ جَاۤءَهُم بَأۡسُنَا تَضَرَّعُوا۟ وَلَـٰكِن قَسَتۡ قُلُوبُهُمۡ وَزَیَّنَ لَهُمُ ٱلشَّیۡطَـٰنُ مَا كَانُوا۟ یَعۡمَلُونَ ۝ فَلَمَّا نَسُوا۟ مَا ذُكِّرُوا۟ بِهِۦ فَتَحۡنَا عَلَیۡهِمۡ أَبۡوَ ٰ⁠بَ كُلِّ شَیۡءٍ حَتَّىٰۤ إِذَا فَرِحُوا۟ بِمَاۤ أُوتُوۤا۟ أَخَذۡنَـٰهُم بَغۡتَةً فَإِذَا هُم مُّبۡلِسُونَ} صدق الله العظيم [سورة الأنعام 42 - 44].

Our fatwa has preceded with Truth that what they call it coronavirus has a source that is not unknown in the decisive grand Quran; (some tiniest-creatur
e) yet they do not encompass knowledge about it::: and the word (some) is built for the upcoming unknown::: and here it is the time of fulfilling the setting of parable has come; the promised challenge from Allah in the Book. As that the new sorts of viruses against the humans which has lengthy lifespan; amphibious::: air-floater::: winter(y)::: summer(y)::: it is equipped with its source; a miracle from Allah to live in all (seasonal) climates in order to be a worldwide chastisement::: and it is not as the epidemic verses that the humans know; in fact::: it has lengthy lifespan; it lives in the human’s body cunning (being contagious) from (one) human being to (another) human being exclusively::: then it lives in the open air after its exiting from the body so it would live as well without a body till when Allah pleases in order to afflict others::: being driven by the command of its Lord afflicting therewith whom He pleases and turning it away from whom He pleases. and the source has a big role it carries out its role with exceeding speed::: and it is some tiny creature yet your eyes do not see it. column21: Some folks on here sure are looking at this through their Proud American privilege lenses. Sheesh. There are a plethora of reasons and justifications international students already admitted for in-person courses should be allowed to retain their visas for online education. Namely that they will not be ensured the same quality of education or access in their home countries::: nor are they getting the same access to the job market that they would have had when they entered into the contract with the University for their education. I agree they need to provide valid justification to attend::: be on campus::: get a visa::: etc::: but some come from war-torn countries; some have no access to the internet or quality to stream live courses; some come from countries that do not value or allow higher education for women; some do not have private spaces to work::: "sit in" on a class::: or study; some do not have resources for food and shelter without financial aid and would have to work full time; and simply that many international time differences are unmanageable and unrealistic from both the student's perspective and the University's course management. I don't know if they should rubber stamp educational visas::: but they absolutely should not rubber stamp a denial; that's ridiculous. Many of these reasons are why these Universities are also keeping some student housing options open and available for American students that don't have the same resources at "home" that they would have on-campus.

column26:
This letter is kinda nutty. What's the point? More virtue signaling?

Student visas are issued to foreign nationals to allow them to take classes::: in person::: in the US. If ALL of a student's classes are online::: there's no need for them to come here. They can take their online classes from their home country...so no need to come to the US and no need for a visa.

This is not a new rule. The DHS announcement is just a reminder of a rule that has existed and has been consistently enforced for decades.

Jesus said to his Apostles:
“As you go::: make this proclamation:

cleanse the lepers::: drive out demons.

no sack for the journey::: or a second tunic:::
or sandals::: or walking stick.

and stay there until you leave.

If the house is worthy:::
let your peace come upon it;
if not::: let your peace return to you.
Whoever will not receive you or listen to your words-\-\
go outside that house or town and shake the dust from your feet.
Amen::: I say to you::: it will be more tolerable
for the land of Sodom and Gomorrah on the day of judgment
than for that town.”

Beth Holtz::: an honorary Notre Dame Monogram winner::: avid philanthropist::: promoter of education and wife of former head football coach Lou Holtz::: passed away last week at the age of 82. The Holtz family will celebrate her life today and tomorrow (Sunday and Monday): https://go.nd.edu/BethHoltz

Please note that the Mass of Christian Burial at 9:30 a.m. on July 6 will have very limited seating due to health protocols. Everyone is welcome to view a livestream of the Mass: https://go.nd.edu/FuneralLiveStream. A limited number of seats will be available in the Eck Visitors' Center auditorium to view a live stream of the Mass.

For those planning on attending the burial at Cedar Grove::: there is no limit on the number attending::: but guests will be expected to wear masks if 6 feet of physical distance is not maintained.

Those wishing to pay their respects are also invited to attend Sunday night's visitation::: which will be held from 6 to 9 p.m. at the Kaniewski Funeral Home::: 3545 North Bendix Dr.::: South Bend.

Psalm 91

Revised Standard Version Catholic Edition

Assurance of God’s Protection

91 He who dwells in the shelter of the Most High:::
who abides in the shadow of the Almighty:::
2 will say to the Lord::: “My refuge and my fortress;
my God::: in whom I trust.”
3 For he will deliver you from the snare of the fowler
and from the deadly pestilence;
4 he will cover you with his pinions:::
and under his wings you will find refuge;
his faithfulness is a shield and buckler.
5 You will not fear the terror of the night:::
nor the arrow that flies by day:::
6 nor the pestilence that stalks in darkness:::
nor the destruction that wastes at noonday.

7 A thousand may fall at your side:::
ten thousand at your right hand;
but it will not come near you.
8 You will only look with your eyes
and see the recompense of the wicked.

9 Because you have made the Lord your refuge:::[a]
the Most High your habitation:::
10 no evil shall befall you:::
no scourge come near your tent.

11 For he will give his angels charge of you
to guard you in all your ways.
12 On their hands they will bear you up:::
lest you dash your foot against a stone.
13 You will tread on the lion and the adder:::
the young lion and the serpent you will trample under foot.

14 Because he cleaves to me in love::: I will deliver him;
I will protect him::: because he knows my name.
15 When he calls to me::: I will answer him;
I will be with him in trouble:::
I will rescue him and honor him.
16 With long life I will satisfy him:::
and show him my salvation.

Psalm 91

Revised Standard Version Catholic Edition

Assurance of God’s Protection

91 He who dwells in the shelter of the Most High:::
who abides in the shadow of the Almighty:::
2 will say to the Lord::: “My refuge and my fortress;
my God::: in whom I trust.”
3 For he will deliver you from the snare of the fowler
and from the deadly pestilence;
4 he will cover you with his pinions:::
and under his wings you will find refuge;
his faithfulness is a shield and buckler.
5 You will not fear the terror of the night:::
nor the arrow that flies by day:::
6 nor the pestilence that stalks in darkness:::
nor the destruction that wastes at noonday.

7 A thousand may fall at your side:::
ten thousand at your right hand;
but it will not come near you.
8 You will only look with your eyes
and see the recompense of the wicked.

9 Because you have made the Lord your refuge:::[a]
the Most High your habitation:::
10 no evil shall befall you:::
no scourge come near your tent.

11 For he will give his angels charge of you
to guard you in all your ways.
12 On their hands they will bear you up:::
lest you dash your foot against a stone.
13 You will tread on the lion and the adder:::
the young lion and the serpent you will trample under foot.

14 Because he cleaves to me in love::: I will deliver him;
I will protect him::: because he knows my name.
15 When he calls to me::: I will answer him;
I will be with him in trouble:::
I will rescue him and honor him.
16 With long life I will satisfy him:::
and show him my salvation.

column3:
To me::: it feels like I have to risk my life for ND::: as currently my only way to return to campus is by jumping on a plane and stopping on 3 different airports.
Who will be liable if I get sick because of my forced return to campus? Or while teaching/
working on campus?
I'm outside the US not because I want to::: but because of border closures. The only option for me to return on time is by plane.
Many ND graduate international students are living with ~$12-15 dollars a day (in case you wonder::: no::: it is not enough and you'll be broken if you get sick. Let's not even talk about wisdom teeth here).
So::: another question::: who is gonna pay my debt if I get sick because ND wants me back?

As an international graduate student at ND::: I want to make clear that ND has done NOTHING to create an inclusive return to campus.
I've been in touch with ISSA and read all the letters from the GradSchool and dthe Provost carefully::: and still::: no one can give us satisfactory answers when we ask about how to safely return to campus while being an international students.
ND has tried to make me believe that "You matter::: your research matters"::: but after looking at all the messages::: it is clear to me that no one cares about my safety.

Also::: are you aware of this? https://
chicago.suntimes

Wastewater samples have been used in the past to measure and track diseases like polio and measles. Now Notre Dame researchers are monitoring wastewater for the coronavirus and could alert public health officials when the virus is present in a community before traditional prediction methods::: like testing::: and estimate how many people in that community are actually carrying the disease.

Learn more about how Notre Dame researchers is working to combat the coronavirus: https://go.nd.edu/UnderstandAndFight

column24:
I believe this policy is great for equity and social justice::: which Notre Dame helped foster in me. I am so glad to think that this might become a standard practice for the university::: as it seeks to ensure that we have an inclusive idea of what it means to be a top student. Research has been clear for over a decade that parental income is one of the top predictors of a students' SAT score::: in addition to parental education level - these tests better measure privilege than educational potential. In addition::: we know the tests have racist outcomes::: and Black and Latinx students in the highest income brackets (e.g. parents making over $200k per year) still underperform on these tests compared to White students in the lowest income bracket (i.e. under $20k)::: even though we know test scores increase with wealth. Finally::: GPA is one of the greatest predictors of college performance - high school GPA is five times more accurate than the ACT in predicting college GPA::: and this correlation exists regardless of the quality of the high school institution. ACT scores have actually shown to have a NEGATIVE correlation with college completion rates - meaning the better you do on the test::: the more likely you are to drop out. For those who are saying you need standardized tests to "know" who the best students are::: you are wrong::: and there is ample research to suggest that standardized tests merely tell us who is most privileged. Instead::: allowing the test to be optional actually helps us live our Catholic values::: of seeing the entirety of a person and all their value::: not just a performance on a four hour test. And this is coming from someone who has scored perfect on the GRE and was in the 99th percentile on the SAT. Love thee::: Notre Dame. https://

column31: This is necessary and may happen for the next year or two depending on how our educational system recovers from the Covid pandemic. Right now there are too many gaps in the way students are being educated and how much these kids are learning so that the groups coming out now to take these tests (if they can even take any tests) are not educated in the same manner as the groups these tests were standardized on. It means you can no longer compare the test scores. There’s been talk for some time of eliminating the ACT/SAT evaluations in college admissions::: this is nothing new. The coronavirus issue just expedited a decision on this matter. There is a lot of research indicating why this test is not the best indicator of collegiate success... it is not just about the well deserving student or the student who worked hardest to get those scores. There are many factors that go into students not testing well who are also well deserving and also work extremely hard.

Firefighters face occupational hazards on a daily basis. Now::: new research shows they face additional risk just by gearing up.

New research from Physics professor Graham Peaslee shows significantly high levels of PFAS::: "forever chemicals" that have been linked to four of the top eight cancers which have been found more commonly in firefighters::: in their turnout gear.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Gear treated with ‘forever chemicals’ poses risk to firefighters

column1:
Not long after the coronavirus pandemic began impacting the nation::: hospitals and other health services began running into shortages of personal protective equipment such as face masks. Typical masks can help prevent the transmission of disease::: but have a one-time use.

Notre Dame researchers are working to develop a new fabric for antimicrobial masks that could potentially be reusable and not only capture viruses::: like the coronavirus::: but also deactivate them.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Notre Dame researchers to create material for new antimicrobial mask

Race::: Violence::: and Protest: A Conversation about the Ongoing Struggle for Justice // Kroc Institute for International Peace Studies // University of Notre Dame

Kroc Institute for International Peace Studies::: University of Notre Dame
June 2::: 2020 at 2:16 PM ·

Join us on Thursday at Noon EDT for a live webinar conversation on race::: violence::: protests::: and the ongoing struggle for justice. Speakers include David Anderson Hooker::: Ashley Bohrer::: Helina Haile::: Ann Mische::: and Karsonya Wise Whitehead (M.A. '93) of Loyola University Maryland.

Register for free at the link below to join the conversation. https://bit.ly/36SUur0

column5: Conversation and reflection about our place in all of this is so important. But we can’t just continue to talk about change::: we need to DO something to enact change. column6:
Unfortunately::: commitments prevent my participation. However::: I should like to ask the question “does not promoting praying for a specific group::: ethnic or racial::: e.g.::: Italians or “people of color”::: subtly yet subconsciously promotes continued divisiveness rather than unity?”. Experience shows that praying for “justice” is praying for a result rather than for the elimination of the underlying cause for injustice overshadows the actual objective for the activity. History shows that until a specific demographic is accepted and integrated into a society as whole it cannot be treated as “belonging” but remains something demanding special attention and “special attention” by its very nature implies “different” which encourages continued divisiveness. Arguably::: promoting divisiveness perpetrates erosion of personal responsibility and individual accountability in favor of collective responsibility.
It is a well-known maxim that “everyone’s responsibility is no one’s responsibility”
.

One of the scribes came to Jesus and asked him:::
“Which is the first of all the commandments?”
Jesus replied::: “The first is this:
Hear::: O Israel!
The Lord our God is Lord alone!
You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart:::
with all your soul::: with all your mind:::
and with all your strength.
The second is this:
You shall love your neighbor as yourself.
There is no other commandment greater than these.”
The scribe said to him::: “Well said::: teacher.
You are right in saying:::
He is One and there is no other than he.
And to love him with all your heart:::
with all your understanding:::
with all your strength:::
and to love your neighbor as yourself
is worth more than all burnt offerings and sacrifices.”
And when Jesus saw that he answered with understanding:::
he said to him::: “You are not far from the Kingdom of God.”
And no one dared to ask him any more questions.

column38: It was the best of times to attend Notre Dame. I was a sophomore. This was such a serious change for me from my provincial background that used to joke about MLK in my hometown living room when I was in high school. My course essay for Dr. Sam Shapiro was on "The Black Revolt" and netted me my first F ever. I rewrote the paper over Christmas break after reading 10 books Prof. Shapiro assigned::: and it profoundly changed my understanding of racism. I acknowledged for the first time that I had grown up a racist! It surprised me.

column45:
I would implore people to please read "The Other America" speech MLK gave.

"Let me say as I've always said::: and I will always continue to say::: that riots are socially destructive and self-defeating.
... But in the final analysis::: a riot is the language of the unheard. And what is it that America has failed to hear? It has failed to hear that the plight of the Negro poor has worsened over the last few years. It has failed to hear that the promises of freedom and justice have not been met. And it has failed to hear that large segments of white society are more concerned about tranquility and the status quo than about justice::: equality::: and humanity. And so in a real sense our nation's summers of riots are caused by our nation's winters of delay. And as long as America postpones justice::: we stand in the position of having these recurrences of violence and riots over and over again. "

Further::: both Chauvin and Thao have had a history of violent incidents and complaints regarding black citizens which have led to lawsuits. To question whether race is a factor is beyond naive. Additionally::: as a resident of the south side of Chicago::: I will agree there is more crime but there is an even stronger sense of community. We are ingrained in systemic racism and the problems are for more complex than what the news simply shares. (The latter was in response to a previous comment made making incorrect assumptions about the south side).

Fr. Jenkins has been running Notre Dame like a business for years so this decision is not surprising. His responses to discrimination and racial injustice on campus have been a bunch of flowery language that says nothing. No true call to action and no promise of change. Is it so hard to condemn hate speech and discrimination?
But I’m sure he doesn’t want to upset the ultra conservatives who are big donors to the school!

I find it so ironic that he said himself in this article::: “First::: we strive to protect the health of our students::: faculty::: staff and their loved ones...If we gave the first principle absolute priority::: our decision about reopening would be easy. We would keep everyone away until an effective vaccine was universally available.” Should this not be the first priority? Is human life and well-being::: not ALWAYS the highest priority? Apparently not when it comes at the expense of the financial well-being of the institution. You’d think a Catholic university would be able to have their priorities a little more in line with Christ’s teachings than that!

column9:
According to A/V professionals at Notre Dame::: there is going to be a lot of distance learning and employees working from home. So::: the typical campus atmosphere will not be in effect. It doesn’t sound like they are even forcing students to show up.

Why would the school go on national TV and the N.Y. Times now to announce opening up in August knowing they can’t offer the full academic and social experience; only to close down in November? Second wave? Flu season? (I thought we weren’t afraid of the flu).

What about Spring semester? TBD?

The only constant in this decision is the September 29th Presidential Debate. You know Trump is not showing if students are not on campus.

Believe me::: I am now praying for a miracle that the virus disappears. There has been plenty of interaction by young people over Memorial Day and we will see consequences::: if any::: in due time. But::: there are plenty of unknowns and the science on this virus is still developing. However::: close quarters interaction (like dormitory living) is the virus’s wheel house.

It’s not about the low death rate among young people::: it’s the fact that people are asking you to be okay with getting sick. That’s not courage and goes against public health 101. But ND wants you back for sure at least for the fall. Oh::: and you won’t be attending any football games.

So::: according to ND::: it’s masks::: testing and contact tracing. I’m for that. If they get 100% compliance::: ND can pull it off and will be the model example.

If they blow it::: students will get sick and ND may face some liability along the lines of Declan Sullivan. Remember that kid taking one for the team? Undue pressure.

But::: at least::: Notre Dame and its conservative base avoid the wrath of Trump.

column30:
I think Father Jenkins makes a pretty clear philosophical point in this. Science cannot in principle give you the moral framework to make decisions that require value judgments -\-\ you can't examine the concept of justice or the principle of fairness with a microscope. You need something beyond science for that. But I hope that::: in today's charged political climate::: his making this obvious point isn't somehow interpreted as an anti-expert view or an anti-scientific
view. It isn't anti-science::: it is in fact very respectful of what science can in principle accomplish::: but it could be perceived that way by people unfamiliar with the distinction between science and moral valuation.

I am personally not sure if the golden mean between the two extremes of recklessly reopening and shutting everything down forever is opening a university of 12:::000+ plus students and a bunch more staff who typically frequent high-density sites (dining halls::: dorms::: the gym::: Debart 101....). I think it still leans too much toward the reckless side. But that's something that reasonable people can arrive at different conclusions about.

column1:
Did you know two Notre Dame landmarks were dedicated on past Memorial Days?

The statue of Fr. Corby::: a Holy Cross priest who served as a military chaplain during the Civil War and twice as Notre Dame president::: was dedicated in 1911. The statue::: which depicts the moment Fr. Corby offered general absolution to all troops before the Battle of Gettysburg::: was recently restored to its place outside of Corby Hall after being moved for construction.

Thirteen years later::: the East Door of the Basilica of the Sacred Heart was dedicated in 1924. The entrance::: inscribed with the familiar phrase "God::: Country::: Notre Dame:::" is a memorial to the students::: alumni and faculty members who sacrificed their lives in World War I.

column5: Around 1890::: freshman Paul Wood put oil to canvas in a painting he called Absolution under Fire. It captured this moment. It is on display at the Snite Museum. Father Corby was the chaplain for the Irish Brigade within the Army of the Potomac. Sadly::: Wood died the following summer in a Chicago fire.

column1:
“If you’re just looking for whether or not someone has the antibody — a yes or no answer — those tests are out there. But simply knowing whether or not someone has the antibody is only part of the picture. We need to know if those levels are declining. Fading immunity would be a major setback to fighting a virus like this.”

Engineering Professor Merlin Bruening and a team of scientists have begun research to develop point-of-care antibody tests that would help public health officials to better understand how an individual’s immunity to COVID-19 lasts over time.

Currently::: these tests aren’t quantitative::: meaning they don’t provide insight into how much of the antibody an individual may have — and that is an important piece of the puzzle.

NEWS.ND.EDU
Researchers work to quantify the human immune response to COVID-19

column6: Then what difference will a vaccine make? A vaccine works by training the immune system to recognize and combat pathogens::: either viruses or bacteria. To do this::: certain molecules from the pathogen must be introduced into the body to trigger an immune response. These molecules are called antigens::: and they are present on all viruses and bacteria. If your body can't build a lasting immunity to it then a vaccine is useless.

column1:
After consultation with experts and health officials to develop a plan to ensure to the greatest extent possible the health and safety of all members of the campus community::: we will welcome students back to campus for the fall semester the week of August 10.

This modified schedule for the 2020-21 fall semester begins two weeks earlier than originally scheduled and will forgo fall break in October and end the semester before Thanksgiving.

The plan includes comprehensive testing for #COVID19::: contact tracing::: quarantine & isolation protocols::: social distancing & mask requirements::: & enhanced cleaning of all campus spaces.

Details: https://go.nd.edu/9c923d

NEWS.ND.EDU
Notre Dame to begin fall semester on campus the week of Aug. 10
column3: Very disappointed in my alma mater. Making a decision far too soon. I can't help but think of the 100:::000 lives lost so far::: and my heart aches for their mourning families::: particularly when I see rushed decisions such as this.
column4: This may be the best thing to do::: but people should realize that this probably won't be a return to campus life as usual. Students and faculty will be wearing masks in sparsely populated classrooms. Football games probably won't have 80:::000 people in the stands although students might be let in if they spread themselves across the stadium. Some classes may still be taught partly or entirely online. If one student gets sick others may suddenly find themselves being quarantined whether they like it or not. Social distancing guidelines will be unpopular and uncomfortable and::: I suspect::: widely violated::: especially on the weekends. Hopefully everyone adapts and it becomes a great new experience::: but my guess is it won't be the same as the old one.
column5: The revised schedule to minimize travel is so smart. I hope other universities who are reopening follow suit.

column17:
Given that the CDC is still advising not to gather in groups at all::: it's not clear how this is going to work. For example::: a class I taught this spring had 18 students and 18 chairs in the room::: with students taking up the entire space around the table—there was in fact no space for me to sit. That's not physically distant. Nor would it have been easy or straightforward
to arrange a Zoom session for remote students as we are asked to do::: as the computer camera would not have been able to capture the board and the class clearly::: I don't think. There are a great many challenges to all this.
column18: I can see the logic in this plan. Students stay on campus::: don't travel for the 2 breaks and then come back 2x.

And if I don’t start reading about some serious hazard pay for faculty and staff-ESPECIALL
Y dining hall and dorm employees (most of who are older and are therefore especially vulnerable) then I’ll just be absolutely disgusted.
column36: So::: what are you going to do when cases inevitably massively spike after the 4th of July? You are aware that there many at-risk faculty::: staff::: and students on your campus::: who are now required to stay in dorms aka buildings with hundreds of people packed into them constantly (with communal bathrooms)? Man::: I want things to go back to normal as much as everyone else because online classes sucked to experience as a senior and this pandemic is absolutely horrible. But this is obviously a mistake. You are essentially assembling a mini-city within a city. There are constant streams of tourists and parents flying in from everywhere to ND on any given week. And there are off campus students and obviously staff and faculty that are going to have to keep going out into SB to get groceries and stuff. Which means you cannot keep the virus from eventually making it’s way onto campus. Which means you are::: inevitably::: GOING to have an epidemic in your hands. Don’t let that happen. Wait.

Congratulations
to all members of the Class of 2020 receiving degrees and graduating from the University of Notre Dame this weekend.

Although it is not the ceremony and weekend for which you have been planning::: we know you will be looking forward with great anticipation to celebrate your Commencement Weekend next year during Memorial Day Weekend::: 2021.

We applaud all parents::: family members::: friends and mentors who helped you in achieving your goals and supported you especially during this unusual and difficult period. Well done everyone!

Best wishes in all your future endeavors::: whether attending post-graduate school::: beginning careers::: or entering a life of service. May God bless you on whatever road your careers or vocations take you.

And may Our Lady::: Notre Dame::: continue to watch over you every day of your lives.

column12: My dad::: a ‘53 grad::: now has a weekly Zoom with his Sorin College roommates. Three 88-year-olds continuing their journey as if no time has passed at all...the only thing strange is figuring out “gallery view”. The Notre Dame family is forever 🍀
column13:
This is a most beautiful::: uplifting essay. You are so gifted and express your gratitude for your “ new” lifelong friend in a way that resonates. I was in the first coed class::: met my husband there in ‘72.....dated after college then parted. Reconnected in November ‘00 and married the next July. This has been a particularly tough week for him (he is not one to show stress) and I had a rather unpleasant experience today. While I am trying to support my husband::: my ND best friend::: I also reached out to another good friend in our class who became a psychologist. My experience was related to someone having covid-angst and not handling it::: and unfortunately I got the brunt. My ND friend was there for me as I sought some explanation from a professional for this strange experience. She’s miles away but made time for me.

Thank you for sharing your story of friendship. There is so much joy here::: even though you’re missing commencement. God bless you. I know you will do well. You’ve lifted my spirits - thank you 🍀
column14: ALWAYS BE A LOYAL FRIEND.. ALWAYS CUS THAT MEANS SOMETHING... GODBLESS PEACE AND LUV ALWAYS ...(*8*)

Gospel Jn 15:9-17
Jesus said to his disciples:
“As the Father loves me::: so I also love you.
Remain in my love.
If you keep my commandments::: you will remain in my love:::
just as I have kept my Father’s commandments
and remain in his love.

“I have told you this so that my joy might be in you
and your joy might be complete.
This is my commandment: love one another as I love you.
No one has greater love than this:::
to lay down one’s life for one’s friends.
You are my friends if you do what I command you.
I no longer call you slaves:::
because a slave does not know what his master is doing.
I have called you friends:::
because I have told you everything I have heard from my Father.
It was not you who chose me::: but I who chose you
and appointed you to go and bear fruit that will remain:::
so that whatever you ask the Father in my name he may give you.
This I command you: love one another.”

Prayer

Father:::
may we whom you renew in baptism
bear witness to our faith by the way we live.
By the suffering::: death::: and resurrection of your Son
may we come to eternal joy.
We ask this through our Lord Jesus Christ::: your Son:::
who lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit:::
one God::: for ever and ever.
column23:
Gospel Jn 14:7-14

Jesus said to his disciples:
“If you know me::: then you will also know my Father.
From now on you do know him and have seen him.”
Philip said to Jesus:::
“Master::: show us the Father::: and that will be enough for us.”
Jesus said to him::: “Have I been with you for so long a time
and you still do not know me::: Philip?
Whoever has seen me has seen the Father.
How can you say::: ‘Show us the Father’?
Do you not believe that I am in the Father and the Father is in me?
The words that I speak to you I do not speak on my own.
The Father who dwells in me is doing his works.
Believe me that I am in the Father and the Father is in me:::
or else::: believe because of the works themselves.
Amen::: amen::: I say to you:::
whoever believes in me will do the works that I do:::
and will do greater ones than these:::
because I am going to the Father.
And whatever you ask in my name::: I will do:::
so that the Father may be glorified in the Son.
If you ask anything of me in my name::: I will do it.”

Alumna Nikole Hannah-Jones awarded Pulitzer Prize

column6: ND should not be bragging about this!!!

column8: This is a disgrace. A politically motivated hatchet job. I'm sure she's a talented journalist but a misguidrd attack on our history is an attack on the republic and the judeic Christian values it was based on.
column10:
I'm sure::: Mrs. Nicole Hannah -Jones would agree with me::: History is an ongoing research for past truth and factual information then::: transformed into documentations which represent true events and "subject matters" always open to rediscovery::: redefining and interpretation.
Therefore::: If your interpretations
of Mrs. Nicole Hannah-Jones Work is Propaganda due to inaccuracies and errors::: then basically all History is Propaganda::: by your standards. Pre-History/
Recent History are documented facts::: however accuracy is still debatable and always. The further we move back into history::: the more interpretative it becomes::: "an interpretation of someone else interpretations. Cross referencing anthropological
examinations and archaeological discoveries get closer to accuracy::: historical truth::: events and patterns::: yet still an interpretation.
I give all historians::: credit::: appreciation :::and respect for their research::: discoveries and simply put::: hard work. I find it disgusting::: when there's disdain and a lack of respect from Critics when a Black Writer or Historians::: researches::: interprets and redefine their Own Black History. American History definitely lack truth and completeness in terms::: of Black History. Through Mrs. Nicole Hannah Jones's hard work and perseverance::: she discovered and redefined Black History therefore::: American History. For an example::: American History gave us untruth about 'Historical Heroic Figures" until::: ongoing research and discoveries revealed some of these Historical Hero's was actually murders::: rapers and thieves. Also::: we have been denied indigenous history which keeps American History further inaccurate. You may criticize Mrs Nicole Hannah-Jones but she has performed extraordinary work as a Reporter for the New York Times and has been selected by the Pulitzer Prize Board::: which consist of editors::: columnists::: media executives::: professors of literature and art. I'm sure their Word and "stamp of approval" means for more::: than any Critic(s).
column11:
As a fellow Alum::: Nikole is family::: and I would never turn my back on family. That being said::: I'm not afraid to call out a family member either.

The premise for the 1619 Project is based on a false narrative of the history of our country. The people behind this project believe that our country was founded on immoral and evil principles when in fact our country was founded on just and moral principles (freedom::: liberty::: and individual rights) that we didn't always apply to various groups as we should have. The great thing about this country::: however::: is that we have been able to overcome and correct those misapplications
and continue to strive to do so wherever we see injustice.

I'm happy that Nikole's writing was recognized. It's just too bad the subject matter was a false narrative of our history.
